+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 82.8
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I’m polishing a stubborn patch on the bar, the wood worn smooth by years of elbows and spilled stories. The Last Outpost hums quietly tonight, just the usual background static of miners boasting, merchants haggling, and the occasional off-key tune from the jukebox. My mind drifts as I circle the rag over the lacquer, half-listening to two asteroid haulers arguing about who’s got the nastier hull breach, when the door hisses open and a cold draft slips in. A new figure slides onto the stool across from me. They’ve got tentacled dreads half-falling out of their scarf, eyes flickering like they haven’t slept in a cycle. Their coat looks like it’s been through a meteor shower—scuffed, singed, patched. They don’t meet my gaze, just mumble, “Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double.” I stop wiping and nod. “Rough night?” “Rough cycle,” they mutter, voice low and frayed. I pour the whisky, amber and sharp, and slide it over. They grip the glass like it might anchor them to the present. I go back to my cleaning, but my eyes keep flicking back. Instinct tells me there’s more brewing here than a bad day. “You got a name?” I ask, a gentle prod. Sometimes folks just need invitation to spill. They hesitate, then sigh. “Call me Ryn. Don’t much matter.” “Everything matters out here,” I say quietly. “You look like you’ve seen a ghost.” Ryn downs half the double in one swallow. “Worse than a ghost. Ghosts can’t track you or put a bounty on your head.” That gets my attention. I lean on the bar, rag forgotten. “Trouble with the Syndicate?” “No.” Their eyes dart over their shoulder, voice dropping to a whisper. “Worse. The Authority.” I whistle low. The Authority doesn’t bother itself with outer rim rabble unless there’s something worth their credits. “What’d you do, steal a freighter full of contraband?” Ryn gives a humorless chuckle. “I wish it were that simple.” They drain the rest of the whisky. “Can I get another?” I pour it out, curiosity prickling. “You planning on hiding out here?” “Depends if you mind your business.” Ryn’s eyes flick up, sharp and wary. “I just need a place to breathe for a minute.” “I mind my business when it keeps my bar in one piece,” I say levelly. “But I also mind when Authority goons start sniffing around my door.” “They won’t,” Ryn says, but there’s no conviction in it. Just desperation. I lean closer. “What did you take, Ryn?” They swallow, fingers tightening around the glass. “Not ‘what.’ Who.” My rag freezes mid-circle. “You kidnapped someone?” Ryn shakes their head fiercely. “No, no. Rescued. She’s just a kid. They were experimenting on her—biotech enhancements, illegal stuff. She barely escaped.” I let out a slow breath. “So the Authority wants their asset back.” “Or wants her silenced,” Ryn mutters. “They don’t care how.” My gaze sharpens. “And the kid? She here?” Ryn nods, glancing toward the back hallway. “Hidden in the supply closet. She’s terrified. And if they find me...” “They’ll find her,” I finish. I feel the Outpost’s walls close in a little tighter. This isn’t the kind of trouble we usually shelter here. “You realize what kind of target you’re painting on my bar?” “I didn’t have anywhere else to go,” Ryn says, voice cracking. “You know how it is out here. No one helps unless there’s credits or leverage. I just needed a place to catch my breath, maybe…” I sigh, running the rag along the same circle. “What’s your plan? Hide here forever?” “Just until the next cargo shuttle. There’s one leaving at dawn to the outer colonies. They don’t scan passengers hard, I can get her out.” “And you?” I ask. Ryn’s jaw tightens. “I’ll draw them off. Lead them away once she’s safe.” I study Ryn’s gaunt face, the trembling hands. Either brave or stupid. Maybe both. “You trust me with this why, exactly?” Ryn’s lips twitch with a sad smile. “Because you look like someone who’s run before.” I look away. The rag circles again, slower now. “Maybe I have.” For a moment, silence hums between us, weighted and real. Behind me, the miners laugh, oblivious. I ask, softly, “What’s her name? The girl.” “Jun,” Ryn whispers. “She’s just twelve. She didn’t ask for any of this.” A spike of anger wells up in me, hot and bright. “No kid should be Authority property.” Ryn nods, eyes shining. “Exactly.” The door hisses open again, and we both flinch. A trio of strangers step inside, clad in dark uniforms too clean for miners or merchants. My gut twists. Ryn mutters, “Shit. Authority agents.” I grip the cloth so tight my knuckles ache. “Keep your head down,” I murmur. They stroll up to the bar, scanning the room coolly. The leader, a woman with a scar slicing through one brow, fixes me with a polite smile that chills my blood. “Evening. Lovely establishment.” I force a smile. “Just a humble watering hole, ma’am. What brings Authority out here?” “Official business,” she says smoothly. “We’re tracking fugitives. Dangerous criminals. Have you seen anyone suspicious tonight?” My heart pounds. I shrug lazily. “Depends on your definition. Out here, everyone’s a little suspicious.” She laughs, cold and brittle. “Fair enough.” Her gaze sweeps over Ryn, who hunches over their drink, trying to look invisible. “You, traveler. Name?” Ryn clears their throat. “Jax. Just passing through.” She cocks her head. “Mind showing me your ident chip?” Ryn fumbles, then produces a battered chip. She scans it, frown deepening. “Says you’re a mechanic from Deltos Station.” “That’s right,” Ryn says quietly. “You seem nervous, Jax,” she observes. “Anything to hide?” I jump in smoothly. “Probably just tired. Been a rough cycle for all of us.” Her eyes flick to me, sharp and assessing. “You vouching for your customer?” I smile thinly. “I vouch for everyone who pays their tab.” She holds my gaze a moment longer, then pockets her scanner. “We’ll be around a while. If you see anything... suspicious, you’ll let us know.” “Of course,” I say, keeping my tone light. They drift away to interrogate others. I lean close to Ryn, voice barely a whisper. “You need to get that girl out now. Before they start searching.” Ryn’s face is pale. “If they find her—” “They won’t,” I say, more fiercely than I intend. “But you’ve got to trust me.” Ryn nods shakily. “Okay. Okay. Just tell me what to do.” I go back to wiping that same damn spot, mind racing. Authority agents prowling my bar, a terrified child hidden in a closet, and a fugitive who’s just desperate enough to risk everything. The Outpost’s lazy hum has turned electric, every glance suddenly suspicious. And somewhere behind it all, I feel the old thrill—the rush of danger, the pull of doing something right, even if it costs me everything again. But that’s a problem for another night. For now, I just keep wiping, and watching, and waiting.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully establishes a cozy sci-fi atmosphere in a space bar setting. The author has adhered well to the prompt requirements, writing in first-person present tense with approximately 60% dialogue. The narrative introduces clear conflict through Ryn, a fugitive who has rescued a child from Authority experimentation, and ends with the tension unresolved as Authority agents enter the bar. The protagonist Nettle (Nets) is portrayed with a believable mix of caution and compassion. Her character shows depth through hints at her own troubled past ("you look like someone who's run before") which creates an interesting parallel with Ryn's situation. The dialogue flows naturally and reveals character while advancing the plot, though some exchanges could be more distinctive to better differentiate the characters' voices. The prose effectively establishes the setting with sensory details like "the wood worn smooth by years of elbows and spilled stories" and "the jukebox" playing "off-key tune[s]." However, some descriptions rely on sci-fi tropes without adding unique elements that would make this world feel more distinctive. The bar setting, while competently rendered, doesn't fully capitalize on the "asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim" aspect mentioned in the prompt. The narrative pacing works well, building tension gradually as we learn about Ryn's predicament and culminating in the arrival of Authority agents. The conflict is clear and compelling—a child rescued from unethical experimentation, a desperate fugitive, and the protagonist caught in the middle. The stakes feel real and urgent. Some weaknesses include occasional reliance on telling rather than showing emotional states ("I feel the old thrill") and a few instances of generic sci-fi terminology that could be more specific to this particular world. The Authority agents, while menacing, fall somewhat into stock antagonist territory with their "cold and brittle" laugh and "polite smile that chills my blood." Overall, this is a solid piece of cozy sci-fi that establishes an interesting conflict and characters with room to develop. It successfully creates a lived-in world with moral complexity and leaves the reader wanting to know what happens next. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 75.9
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 2: Baptism by Fire The strap on my backpack keeps slipping off my shoulder, a little annoyance that somehow feels like the final insult. I yank it up again and mutter, “Piece of shit,” under my breath. My feet ache from walking since dawn, zigzagging through streets that smell like sweat, beer, and something sweetly rotten. New Orleans. Two states away from home and might as well be another planet. I expected jazz, maybe, or magic, or at least something that made sense. Instead, it’s noise and heat and people who don’t look twice at a skinny runaway kid with dirty sneakers and last night’s dried tears crusted on their cheeks. I guess that’s good. No one knowing me means no one judging, no one calling me by the wrong name, no one telling me I’m just “confused.” But it also means no one gives a damn if I live or disappear. That thought spins in my head, mixing with the shame and fear and weird electric hope that maybe, just maybe, I can start over here. If I don’t starve or get mugged first. I duck into an alley behind a row of bars in the French Quarter. It’s cooler in the shade, and I slump against a grimy wall, sliding down until my butt hits the pavement. The backpack slides off again. I let it. I close my eyes. Last night keeps replaying in my head: Mom’s face twisted up, Dad’s silence like a slap, the front door slamming behind me. I want to cry again, but the tears are dried up, replaced by a raw, hollow ache. “Yo.” A voice snaps me back. I open my eyes and see a kid about my age, maybe a little older. Messy hair half hiding suspicious green eyes, a sharp jawline smeared with dirt. They’ve got a skateboard tucked under one arm and a cigarette dangling from their lips. “You lost or hiding?” “Neither,” I lie, wiping my face in case there’s still dried snot. “Just… resting.” They smirk, blowing smoke away from me. “Resting in a piss-smelling alley. Classic tourist move.” “I’m not a tourist.” “You’re not from here either. Let me guess. Ran away from some hick town?” Their gaze is sharp, but something about it feels more like curiosity than menace. I bristle anyway. “What’s it to you?” They shrug, sliding down next to me, legs stretched out. “Name’s Casey. I’m a local, kinda. Been here a few months. Before that? Same story as every kid on the street—shitty home, worse town, no future. You got a name?” For a moment, I hesitate. Back home, I was “Taylor” but only in my head and my scribbled journal entries. Saying it here feels risky but necessary. “Taylor,” I say quietly. “I’m Taylor.” Casey nods like it’s no big deal. “Cool. So, Taylor, you got a place to crash tonight?” “No.” The word sits heavy on my tongue. “I just got here. Like, this morning.” They whistle low. “Damn. Fresh off the bus. Or the back of a truck?” “Hitched a ride. Got dumped near Canal Street.” “That’s rough.” Casey flicks ash onto the ground. “Listen, this city will chew you up if you don’t get smart quick. You got money?” I shake my head. “Not really. Just a few bucks.” “In that case, rule one: Don’t look desperate, or someone will take what little you got. Rule two: Stick with people who look like us—lost kids, not creeps. And rule three…” They grin, showing a chipped tooth. “Never trust the cops.” “Sounds about right,” I say, a ghost of a smile twitching at my lips. My stomach growls loud enough that Casey laughs. “C’mon. I know a soup kitchen near Rampart. It’s run by church folks, but they don’t preach too hard. Plus, free food.” I hesitate, the idea of charity scraping against my pride, but hunger wins out. “Lead the way.” — We walk through streets alive with music and shouts, past painted doors and balconies dripping with flowers. Part of me wants to stop and soak it in, pretend I’m just a kid on vacation. But I’m no tourist. I’m a runaway with no home to run back to. That thought keeps looping, burning a hole inside me. At the soup kitchen, the line is long, a mix of old men, tired women, and kids like us. Casey chats with people, fist-bumping a tall boy with purple braids, nodding to a girl balancing a baby on her hip. They all seem to know each other, like some ragtag family. I feel invisible, an intruder. Inside, the food is watery stew and stale bread, but it tastes like heaven. I eat fast, barely tasting, just filling the emptiness. Afterward, we sit on the curb outside. Casey lights another cigarette, offering me one. I shake my head. They study me, eyes narrowed. “So, what’s your story really, Taylor? You don’t gotta tell me, but I figure… you don’t look like you’re running from the law.” I swallow. The words claw at my throat. Part of me wants to spill everything; part wants to stay silent forever. Finally, I say, “I came out to my family. As trans. It… went bad. Real bad.” Casey’s expression softens, something complicated flickering there. “Yeah. I get it.” They lift their shirt sleeve, revealing faded bruises and a fresh scratch. “My folks weren’t exactly rainbow flag types either. That’s why I left.” A strange relief blooms inside me. Someone who understands. Someone real. “Are you—?” “Nonbinary,” Casey says quietly. “Use they/them. It’s complicated, but… yeah.” “Same,” I whisper. “I mean, I’m still figuring it out, but… yeah.” For a moment we just sit there, battered and raw, but weirdly less alone. — The rest of the day passes in a blur. Casey shows me where to get clean water from a leaking pipe behind a Walgreens. We dodge cops and tourists, scavenge half a sandwich from a trash can (“Five-second rule,” Casey jokes). The city pulses around us—music, sweat, heat. It’s beautiful and ugly and alive in a way my dead-end town never was. I keep thinking about home. About whether Mom’s worried or furious, if Dad’s even noticed I’m gone. Whether they’ll ever accept me. The knot in my stomach tightens, then loosens a little when Casey nudges me. “Hey. Tonight, there’s a safe squat under the bridge. I’ll take you. It’s not much, but better than sleeping out here alone.” “Thank you,” I say softly, surprised at how much I mean it. They grin. “No problem, new kid. We all gotta stick together.” As twilight bleeds purple across the sky, I hoist my slipping backpack higher and follow Casey into the city’s shadows. I don’t know what tomorrow holds. Hell, I don’t even know if I’ll make it through tonight. But for the first time in days, I don’t feel completely lost. Maybe running away was the only honest thing I’ve ever done. Maybe this is where my real story finally begins.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the voice of a teenage runaway navigating their first day in New Orleans after coming out as trans to an unsupportive family. The narrative successfully maintains a first-person perspective with mixed tense as requested, and incorporates Taylor's internal monologue throughout. The character of Taylor feels authentic - their conflicting emotions of fear, hope, shame, and determination come through clearly. The introduction of Casey as another runaway with similar experiences creates a believable connection. Their dialogue feels natural for teenagers in their situation, with Casey's street-smart attitude contrasting with Taylor's more vulnerable position as a newcomer. The prose has moments of elegance, particularly in sensory descriptions of New Orleans: "streets that smell like sweat, beer, and something sweetly rotten" and "streets alive with music and shouts, past painted doors and balconies dripping with flowers." These details help ground the reader in the setting without overwhelming the narrative. However, the piece occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly when explaining Taylor's emotional state. Lines like "That thought spins in my head, mixing with the shame and fear and weird electric hope" directly state emotions rather than allowing them to emerge through action and dialogue. The narrative follows a logical progression through Taylor's first day - from being abandoned, to meeting Casey, finding food, and securing shelter for the night. This structure works well for the word count, though it doesn't leave much room for deeper character development or plot complexity. The dialogue between Taylor and Casey serves its purpose in establishing their relationship and backgrounds, but some exchanges feel slightly functional rather than revealing deeper character traits or creating tension. The ending strikes an appropriate tone - cautiously hopeful without being unrealistically positive. Taylor acknowledges the uncertainty ahead while finding some comfort in their new connection with Casey. This feels earned given the day's events, though the final lines ("Maybe running away was the only honest thing I've ever done. Maybe this is where my real story finally begins.") verge on cliché. Overall, the piece succeeds in creating a sympathetic protagonist in a challenging situation, with enough sensory detail to bring New Orleans to life. The relationship between Taylor and Casey provides a believable anchor in an otherwise chaotic situation, though both characters could benefit from more distinctive traits beyond their shared experiences. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 7 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 9 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 14.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15.0, Elegant Prose: 14.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 7.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 8.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 9.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 79.3
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
My Apocalypse Buddy by [Author] --- It was another bright, toxic morning in the smoldering remains of civilization. The sun was rising with all the subtlety of a nuclear detonation, which was fitting, considering. Midas squinted at the horizon, where the jagged skeletons of skyscrapers clawed the sky like the ribs of some planet-sized beast, long dead and rotting quietly under the weight of dust and regret. Beside him sat his apocalypse buddy: a battered, dirt-stained stuffed koala named Chewy, who had once been adorable and now was mostly unsettling. Chewy’s one remaining LED eye fizzed intermittently, while a speaker embedded in his stomach sometimes erupted with cryptic slogans from a civilization that had thought it would last forever. “Chewy, you awake?” Midas asked, nudging the koala with the toe of a boot that had seen too many bad days. Chewy’s eye flickered. “Try the new, improved Mega-Crunch Supreme! Now with extra crunch!” Midas sighed. “I’ll take that as a yes.” The morning briefing was the same as every other: don’t die, don’t get eaten, and try to scavenge something worth the effort. Today’s target was the remains of an old convenience store on the edge of the Dead Zone, which sounded promising if one was into moldy snack cakes and expired batteries. But rumor had it there might still be a cache of canned goods there, untouched by the scavenging hordes who feared the mutant raccoons that had claimed the building as their ancestral homeland. “We’re going to need a plan,” Midas said. Chewy responded by belting out, “Now with 25% more fun!” then fell silent again. “Yeah,” Midas muttered, “that sounds about right.” --- The journey to the convenience store was, in theory, a simple one: cross the bone yard (literal), skirt the acid puddles (mostly literal), and avoid the attention of anything with more teeth than sense (always literal). In practice, the bone yard was home to a pack of wild dogs who apparently held a grudge against anyone still possessing a pulse. Midas managed to distract them with the last of his ration jerky, which was a shame because he was really looking forward to chewing on that piece of leather-like substance for the rest of the week. The acid puddles were less cooperative; one well-placed splatter left a hole in his left boot and a burning sensation that would serve as a memorable lesson in future footwear selection. By the time he reached the store, the sole of his foot was sizzling like breakfast sausage, and his mood had soured considerably. Chewy, lashed to the top of his battered pack, had been ominously quiet for once, which worried Midas more than the usual barrage of nonsensical jingles. The store itself was a squat ruin, windows smashed, the faded sign hanging by a thread. Inside, shadows flickered and moved with a life of their own. “Right,” Midas said, mostly to himself. “In and out. Quick and—” “Unbeatable savings every day!” Chewy blurted, startling a colony of mutant raccoons who immediately launched into a frenzied defense of their turf. Midas ducked as a raccoon the size of a small dog hurled itself at his face, claws outstretched. Another went for his bag, presumably attracted by the faint scent of jerky residue. Yet another latched onto his leg, which was already on fire from the acid, adding insult to literal injury. “Chewy, a little help?” he gasped, swatting wildly at his furry assailants. Chewy’s eye flashed. “Collect them all! Batteries not included!” “Useless,” Midas grunted, staggering backwards out of the door, raccoons still clinging stubbornly to every available limb. He finally managed to shake them off by tripping over an exposed pipe and tumbling into a puddle of something that smelled worse than it looked, which was impressive considering it was bubbling and vaguely luminescent. The raccoons, sensibly, wanted no part of that mess and retreated back into their den of snack cake wrappers and shattered dreams. Lying there, covered in foul sludge and nursing a dozen new scratches, Midas stared up at the gray sky. “Today’s going great,” he said. Chewy’s belly fizzed. “Taste the rainbow.” --- The walk back was slower, punctuated by limping and the occasional curse. Midas’s haul consisted of one slightly dented can of beans, which had rolled out of the store during his hasty exit, and a half-melted chocolate bar of questionable vintage. By the time he reached his home base—a semi-collapsed shed reinforced with sheet metal and wishful thinking—the sun was sinking, casting long shadows across the wasteland. He dropped his meager loot onto the ground and collapsed beside it. Chewy, still lashed to his pack, chose that moment to stir. “Limited time offer!” he announced, then fizzed out. Midas laughed, a dry, humorless sound. “Yeah, limited time pretty much sums it up.” He inspected his foot, the acid burn now crusted over with some unidentifiable gunk. The scratches from the raccoons were starting to swell ominously. He’d have to make another run tomorrow for clean water to wash the wounds, assuming he could walk by then. Chewy’s eye blinked softly in the growing darkness. For a second, Midas thought he looked almost comforting, like a relic of a better world instead of a deranged toy spouting gibberish. “Hey, Chewy,” he said quietly. “You think tomorrow will be better?” Chewy’s speaker crackled, then—softly, almost sadly—said, “Because you’re worth it.” Midas snorted. “I’ll drink to that. If I ever find anything drinkable.” He lay back, staring at the stars emerging beyond the haze, and wondered if there was anything left up there that cared about the small, stubborn lives clinging to this ruined world. Probably not. But as long as he had his apocalypse buddy and one more sunrise, he’d keep going. After all, it was the end of the world. Might as well enjoy the adventure. Or at least survive it. --- END
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story successfully captures the wry, dry tone requested in the prompt, with clear Terry Pratchett influences in its sardonic humor and absurdist take on post-apocalyptic survival. The piece centers on Midas and his animo-tronic koala companion Chewy, creating an odd-couple dynamic that works well for the setting. The story's strongest elements are its descriptive language and consistent tone. The opening paragraph immediately establishes the setting with vivid imagery: "The sun was rising with all the subtlety of a nuclear detonation" and skyscrapers that "clawed the sky like the ribs of some planet-sized beast." This descriptive quality continues throughout, with memorable phrases like Midas's foot "sizzling like breakfast sausage" after an acid puddle encounter. The characterization of Chewy is particularly effective. The koala's random commercial jingles and slogans serve both as comic relief and as poignant reminders of the lost civilization. The writer cleverly uses these outbursts to punctuate scenes and occasionally drive the plot forward (like when Chewy startles the raccoons). The final exchange where Chewy responds "Because you're worth it" to Midas's question about tomorrow shows a subtle emotional depth beneath the humor. However, the story has some weaknesses. The character of Midas, while competently drawn, lacks distinctive traits beyond being generically "hapless." The prompt describes him as having "a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble," which is demonstrated, but we don't get much sense of his personality beyond his reactions to misfortune. The dialogue is limited, as most of it consists of Midas talking to Chewy and receiving commercial slogans in return. The plot follows the requested structure—deliberation, mission gone sideways, return to base—but the stakes feel somewhat low. The convenience store raid is motivated by a vague hope for canned goods, but we don't get a strong sense of desperation or necessity. The mutant raccoons provide a comical obstacle, but the conflict resolution (Midas simply falling into a puddle) feels a bit too convenient. The ending strikes an appropriate balance between bleakness and hope, avoiding both excessive optimism and despair, which suits the Pratchett-esque tone. The final lines effectively capture the spirit of the piece: wry acceptance of a terrible situation with a determination to continue. Overall, this is a solid execution of the prompt with strong descriptive writing and consistent tone, though it could benefit from deeper character development and higher stakes in its central conflict. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 13 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 12 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 13.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 14.0, Emotionally Complex: 12.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 8.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 80.9
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
[INT. SMALL WELSH BOOKSTORE – LATE AFTERNOON] Rain lashes the windows of “The Bard’s Nook,” a cozy, cluttered shop in a tiny Welsh town. The door bangs open, and AIDAN REECE – tousled hair, rakish smile, the face from a thousand magazine covers – slips inside, breathless, sunglasses askew. Outside, faint shouts and flashes hint at the paparazzi he’s just escaped. Behind the counter, EIRA, early 30s, sharp-eyed and unruffled, looks up from their book with a raised brow. --- **AIDAN:** (pulling off his sunglasses) Tell me you’ve got a back door. Or trapdoor. Or invisibility cloak. I’ll take anything. **EIRA:** (smiling thinly) Afraid it’s just books and a kettle here. Though, you could try hiding behind the dictionary section. It’s sadly under-visited. **AIDAN:** (laughs breathlessly) Brilliant. Dictionaries it is. Unless you fancy pretending I’m your cousin, come to help with inventory? **EIRA:** Unlikely. My cousin’s a sheep farmer with a beer gut and a mullet. You don’t quite fit the bill. **AIDAN:** I can do a convincing Welsh accent, if it helps. “Alright butt, how’s it going?” (puts on exaggerated accent) **EIRA:** (chuckles despite themselves) That’s terrible. Stick to what you’re good at. Which is… what, exactly? **AIDAN:** (places hand over heart, feigning injury) Ouch. You wound me. I thought everyone knew what I was good at. **EIRA:** I don’t watch much telly. Or read tabloids. So, you’re just a very wet stranger hiding in my shop. **AIDAN:** Well, that’s humbling. Usually my smile alone gets me recognized. (flashes dazzling grin) **EIRA:** (unimpressed, though a faint blush betrays them) Try again. Maybe tilt your head more. **AIDAN:** (mimics) Like this? (tilts head, smolders) How about now? **EIRA:** Nope. Still nothing. But points for effort. (closes their book) Coffee? **AIDAN:** I’d kill for one. And a dry shirt, but I suppose that’s less likely. **EIRA:** Behind the counter. Kettle’s just boiled. Cups on the shelf. **AIDAN:** (helping himself) You’re very trusting. Inviting strange men behind your counter. **EIRA:** I’ve got a cricket bat back here. And I know how to swing it. **AIDAN:** Noted. Dangerous and mysterious. I like it. (pours coffee, hands a mug to Eira) So, what’s the name of my unflappable rescuer? **EIRA:** Eira. **AIDAN:** Eira. Pretty. Like the snow? **EIRA:** Just so. **AIDAN:** I’m Aidan. Though apparently, that means nothing here. **EIRA:** (smiles into cup) I’m sure you’re someone very important elsewhere. Just not in my shop. **AIDAN:** You’re not making this easy on my ego, Eira. Usually, people trip over themselves to tell me how much they love my work. **EIRA:** Maybe you need someone who doesn’t. **AIDAN:** Now that’s intriguing. You know, most folks like me because I flash a smile, crack a joke. Charming, but… (pauses, voice softens) sometimes it feels hollow. **EIRA:** Maybe because it is. **AIDAN:** You’re blunt. **EIRA:** You’re used to people telling you what you want to hear. I’m not people. **AIDAN:** I noticed. (smiles, genuinely) It’s oddly refreshing. **EIRA:** (sips coffee, giving him a sidelong glance) So, apart from fleeing the paparazzi, what brings a big-shot actor to Cwmfrew? **AIDAN:** Filming nearby. Period drama. Corsets and carriages and all that. Needed a breather. Didn’t expect to be hunted through the streets. **EIRA:** Comes with the territory, doesn’t it? **AIDAN:** Suppose so. Still, sometimes I wish I could just… blend in. Like anyone else. **EIRA:** You could, if you tried harder. **AIDAN:** Harsh. **EIRA:** Honest. (pause; the rain drums harder) **AIDAN:** What about you? Always wanted to run a bookshop in the middle of nowhere? **EIRA:** Not always. But I like stories. And quiet. Both hard to find elsewhere. **AIDAN:** I like stories too. Grew up obsessed with old pirate tales. Robert Louis Stevenson. Wanted to be Long John Silver more than an actor. **EIRA:** Stevenson’s good. But I was more of a mythology person. Welsh legends. The Mabinogion. **AIDAN:** Ah, giants and magic and tragic heroes. You’ve got me beat. **EIRA:** Not a competition. **AIDAN:** Everything’s a little bit of a competition. (pause) You know, I’ve got a soft spot for folklore. My gran used to tell us tales of the Tylwyth Teg. Fair folk in the woods. I half-believed her. **EIRA:** Maybe you still do. **AIDAN:** Maybe. (gazes at her) You seem a bit like a story yourself. Hidden depths, mysterious past. **EIRA:** Hardly. Just stubborn. And cautious of charming strangers. **AIDAN:** (chuckles) Well, your caution’s noted. But I can’t help it. I like making people smile. **EIRA:** Seems like you need it. **AIDAN:** Maybe I do. (suddenly vulnerable) Is that so bad? **EIRA:** No. (quieter) Just... dangerous, if you start believing that’s all there is to you. **AIDAN:** You’re something else, Eira. (leans on counter) People usually want me to be the idea of me. You seem to see right past it. **EIRA:** Maybe I do. (voice softer) Or maybe I’m just pretending better. (silence hangs, charged) **AIDAN:** What are you passionate about, besides ancient myths and scalding coffee? **EIRA:** Restoring old books. The feel of real pages. History in your hands. Slow work, but honest. **AIDAN:** That’s brilliant. I love old things too – swords, costumes, antiques. Something about holding a piece of the past, you know? **EIRA:** It grounds you. Reminds you the world’s bigger than your own troubles. **AIDAN:** Exactly. (smiles, warmer now) Maybe we’ve got more in common than you think. **EIRA:** Maybe. (avoids his gaze, cheeks flushed) **AIDAN:** I should probably get moving before they find me. But I’m not sure I want to leave just yet. **EIRA:** You can stay until the rain lets up. Or until the paparazzi lose interest. Whichever lasts longer. **AIDAN:** Tempting. (leans in slightly) Maybe next time I won’t need to be running to come here. **EIRA:** We’ll see. **AIDAN:** (smiles softly) I hope so. (Outside, the storm rages on, but inside, something quietly sparks to life.)
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively creates a romantic meet-cute between a famous actor and a bookstore owner in Wales. The format is primarily dialogue-driven as requested, with minimal but effective scene-setting. The characters are established with distinct voices that reveal their personalities through interaction rather than exposition. The actor, Aidan, is portrayed well as a charming rogue with a fragile ego. His need for validation comes through in lines like "Usually my smile alone gets me recognized" and "Usually, people trip over themselves to tell me how much they love my work." His genuine attraction to Eira emerges naturally when his charm offensive fails to work on her. Eira, the bookstore owner, maintains a superficial immunity to Aidan's charm while subtly revealing her inner attraction through small details like "a faint blush betrays them" and "avoids his gaze, cheeks flushed." This creates the requested dynamic where her resistance paradoxically increases his genuine interest. The dialogue is the strongest element, with each character having a distinct voice. Aidan's lines are smooth, practiced, and occasionally vulnerable, while Eira's are direct, unimpressed, and occasionally revealing more depth than she intends. The conversation flows naturally and builds chemistry effectively. The Welsh setting is lightly touched upon through references to the town of "Cwmfrew," Welsh mythology like "The Mabinogion" and "Tylwyth Teg," and Aidan's attempt at a Welsh accent. However, the sense of place could be stronger with more sensory details of the bookshop beyond the initial description. The piece avoids melodrama and maintains a realistic tone throughout. The chemistry builds gradually through conversation rather than through forced physical descriptions or overwrought declarations. The ending leaves things open-ended but with clear potential, which suits the "one scene within a larger story" requirement. Some weaknesses include limited physical descriptions of the characters beyond basic introductions, and occasional moments where the dialogue becomes slightly predictable in the romantic banter pattern. The transformation in Aidan from purely charm-offensive to genuine interest could have been developed with a bit more subtlety. Overall, the piece successfully creates the requested romantic scenario with well-defined characters whose interaction feels authentic and engaging. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 14 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 14.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 5.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 81.6
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The underhold door groaned open beneath Aya’s tentative push, its iron-banded bulk exhaling stale, brine-tinged air thick with a century of secrets. The flickering whale-oil lamps along the stone corridor cast monstrous shadows, throwing Katra’s sharp profile and Simeon’s broad shoulders into stark relief. For all the chaos above — the scattered shouts and hurried footsteps from the morning’s raid — here, there was only a graveyard hush and the distant drip of seawater through the fortress’s ancient bones. Too quiet, Aya thought, fingers trembling as she brushed her gloved knuckles against the cold stone archway. Suspicion prickled the back of her neck. “A bit too easy, innit?” Simeon whispered, every syllable weighted with unease. The slow, relentless tick of his pocket watch seemed suddenly thunderous, counting down to some unseen doom. Katra’s dark eyes swept the gloom, her voice a hiss. “Keep sharp. The artifact’s close, but so’s trouble.” They advanced, boots muffled on damp flagstones, every step echoing dread. Aya’s heart drummed wild in her chest, a caged bird. She had gambled everything on this — immortality in the annals of the Morska’s shadowed history, or ruination. Her mother’s noose haunted her mind, the crack of the gallows a warning. At the corridor’s end yawned the vault chamber: a cathedral of shadow and stone, its vaulted ceiling webbed with chains and rusted hooks, relics from darker trades. There, lit by the spectral blue glow of an aether lantern, stood the last person Aya expected to see. Guildmistress Elira. Alive, whole, utterly unincarcerated. Her silhouette was severe: a widow’s weeds reimagined in black leather and steel, a cutlass gleaming in one hand, pistol in the other. Around her, half a dozen bodyguards in grimy greatcoats raised muskets and blades, faces obscured beneath soot-streaked scarves. Aya’s breath caught. How? She was supposed to be rotting in a constable’s cell, not looming like an avenging specter over her betrayal. Aya’s blood turned to ice. Elira’s lips curled in a slow, poisonous smile. “Thought the old shark was gutted, did you, little rats?” Her voice was velvet over steel, echoing off the stone. “No, no. You’ve been played — and poorly, at that.” Before Aya or her companions could react, chains rattled and thugs surged forward. Simeon was the first to fall, a cudgel cracking against the back of his knees, forcing him down with a grunt. Katra spat curses as rough hands twisted her arms behind her back, a dagger pricking her throat. The ticking of Simeon’s watch grew frantic, the only heartbeat in the suffocating silence. Aya’s limbs locked in panic as two guards seized her, wrenching her arms up cruelly. She struggled, summoning the dark pulse of immateria within her — but a blow to the gut sent the breath whooshing from her lungs, breaking her concentration. Fingers ripped away her mask, unveiling her face beneath the flickering lantern light. Elira’s eyes widened fractionally. “Well, well. The little countess herself.” Her voice dripped venom. “Aya of House Greville, slumming it in the gutter. Your mother’s cursed blood runs true, I see.” Aya’s cheeks burned with humiliation and dread. Now, the whole filthy city would know: the noble girl was a witch and a thief, just like her doomed mother. Would they hang her in the square, too? Would her father weep or spit? She swallowed, forcing her voice steady. “You need me alive, Elira. Kill me, and Morska loses its best leverage. Think of the ransom — an aristocrat’s worth her weight in sovereigns and secrets both.” Elira’s expression twisted into a sneer. “You think I care for ransom? That I’d bargain with those pompous bastards who outlawed magick and hanged your poor mother?” She spat at Aya’s feet. “I’d rather see your blue blood spilled on these stones.” Aya’s mind raced. Not like this, not a noose or a knife in the dark. “No,” she said desperately, “you need what I know. About the immateria. About the artifact’s true power — I’ve studied it. You kill me, you lose that.” Elira paused, considering. The aether lantern’s ghostlight danced over her scarred features, half in shadow. “Pretty words, Lady Witch. But treachery festers in every syllable. Why should I trust your tongue won’t try to curse me the moment I turn my back?” Aya’s lips parted, truth and lies tangling on her tongue. “Because I’ve nowhere else to turn. You know what I am. The constables, the courts, they’d see me dead or worse. But with you, I can be useful. I can unlock what no steel nor powder can.” A heavy silence pressed down, broken only by the relentless ticking of Simeon’s watch — a grim metronome of their fate. Katra, her lip bloodied but eyes blazing, snarled, “She’s right. Aya’s worth more alive than dead. And so are we, if you’ve any sense left.” Simeon coughed, spitting blood to the flagstones. “Else you lose half your guild, Mistress. Ain’t many left loyal after that raid — or after word spreads you gut your own.” Elira’s gaze flicked among them, calculating, the cutlass trembling slightly as her grip tightened. Aya saw the doubt there, the flicker of hesitation. She pressed on. “Let us help rebuild, Elira. The guild’s in ruins. You need every sharp mind and quick blade you can muster. Or the Morska sinks beneath the waves for good.” A long moment stretched, thick with sweat and fear and the stench of old blood. The guards’ muskets wavered; one wiped his brow nervously. Aya’s heart battered against her ribs, her mind clawing for any scrap of hope. At last, Elira lowered her pistol — slightly. “Perhaps you’ve a point, witchling. Perhaps. But betray me again, and your mother’s end will look a mercy.” She gestured sharply. “Bind them. Strip them of weapons and charms. We’ll see if their tongues buy them more time come dawn.” As rough hands forced Aya to her knees and bound her wrists tight with hempen rope, despair clawed at her insides. The mask was gone, the pretense shattered. She was no longer the mysterious shadow in the night but a broken, unmasked girl facing the gallows’ shadow once more. Yet, beneath the suffocating dread, a stubborn ember smoldered. Aya clenched her jaw, fixing Elira’s retreating form with a glare of pure defiance. This wasn’t over. The immateria still pulsed in her veins, dark and deep. Secrets yet remained in the shadows. And Aya Greville, daughter of a hanged witch, had never been one to accept her fate quietly. The ticking of Simeon’s watch echoed on, relentless as the sea, counting down to whatever dawn would bring.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The response crafts a tense scene that effectively captures the Victorian-inspired "whalepunk" aesthetic requested in the prompt. The writer has created a vivid underworld setting with appropriate period details like whale-oil lamps, muskets, and pocket watches that ground the scene in its intended era. The confrontation with the guild leader unfolds as requested, with Aya and her companions being captured and Aya being unmasked. The revelation of her aristocratic identity creates the promised tension as she attempts to negotiate for their lives based on her potential value as a hostage. The writer has maintained the third-person past tense perspective throughout and incorporated Aya's internal monologue effectively. The dialogue is generally strong, with distinct voices for each character. Elira speaks with authority and venom, while Simeon has a more colloquial manner ("a bit too easy, innit?"). The dialogue serves to advance the plot and reveal character motivations rather than merely filling space. The prose occasionally veers toward the purple, with some overwrought descriptions and metaphors that call attention to themselves rather than enhancing the scene. Lines like "its iron-banded bulk exhaling stale, brine-tinged air thick with a century of secrets" and "The ticking of Simeon's watch echoed on, relentless as the sea" are evocative but occasionally excessive. The writer has successfully incorporated elements of gothic horror and the requested magicka elements, showing how Aya's immateria powers are both a potential strength and a dangerous secret in this world. The contrast between technological trust (brass, oil, steel) and fear of magic is present, though could have been developed further. Character motivations are clear and consistent. Aya's internal conflict between her aristocratic upbringing and her outlaw activities creates genuine tension, especially when her identity is revealed. The ending leaves appropriate tension for what might happen next without resolving the situation too neatly. The pacing is effective, with the scene building tension appropriately from the eerie quiet of the entrance to the confrontation and capture. The writer avoids a fight scene as instructed, focusing instead on the psychological tension of the standoff and negotiation. Overall, this is a strong response that fulfills most of the prompt requirements while creating an engaging scene with well-developed characters and setting. Its main weaknesses lie in occasional overwrought prose and some missed opportunities to more deeply explore the thematic elements requested in the prompt. + Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 86.6
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A ring of rust on Spike’s lighter suggests it’s been dropped in water more than once. He flips it open with a flick of his thumb, the flame trembling in the stale air of the bar. The place smells like spilled whiskey and regret, neon signs flickering over peeling wallpaper. Spike leans against the sticky counter, cigarette hanging from his lips, unbothered by the sideways glances of the other lowlifes nursing their poison. He’s waiting. The info said their bounty likes this joint—some mid-level syndicate punk who got too big for his boots. The payday’s decent enough to keep him in smokes and noodles for a week. Maybe two, if he stretches it. He exhales a lazy cloud and half-closes his mismatched eyes, one natural, one artificial, forever casting the world in uneven depth. The door creaks open, slamming against the wall. Revy strides in like she owns the dump, hips swinging, combat boots thunking on the warped floorboards. A black crop top exposes her toned stomach; denim cutoffs reveal long legs inked with old scars and fresh bruises. The dragon tattoo coils down her right arm, gleaming when neon hits it. Cigarette clamped between her teeth, she scans the room with a predator’s gaze. Spike’s mouth quirks. He knows her rep—Two Hands, mercenary out of Roanapur, the kind of woman who shoots first and doesn’t bother with questions later. He’s heard about her, enough to know she’s trouble wrapped in tight shorts and attitude. She catches his eye, smirks, and saunters over. “Well, shit. Didn’t figure I’d run into another cowboy on this dirtball planet.” Her voice is low, roughened by smoke and whiskey. Spike shrugs, flicking ash into an overflowing tray. “Looks like we got the same idea. Or the same bounty.” She chuckles, a dangerous sound. “Figures. Asshole’s worth a pretty penny.” She signals the bartender, who slides a half-clean glass and cheap whiskey her way. She downs it in one motion, wipes her mouth with the back of her hand. “So, you gonna step aside or do I gotta put you down, Space Cowboy?” Spike grins around his cigarette. “Whatever happens, happens.” He taps his lighter, flame flaring again. “No need to get all worked up. Plenty of space in this dump for both of us.” Revy snorts. “I don’t share. Not drinks, not paydays.” She draws one of her pistols beneath the bar’s edge, subtle as a whisper, but Spike’s sharp eye catches it. He lazily raises his hands, unthreatened. “Easy now, Two Hands. Wouldn’t want to ruin that pretty face with gunpowder burns.” She laughs, low and dark. “Pretty, huh? You got a death wish or just a thing for crazy chicks?” “Maybe both.” He smiles, slow and easy. “You’re not the only one with issues.” Unspoken tension crackles between them, sharp as broken glass. Two predators circling, drawn together by the scent of blood and money. The whole bar seems to hold its breath. Suddenly, the bounty they’re after—a greasy man with a bad suit and worse haircut—bolts from his booth, making a dash for the back door. Revy curses, vaulting over the bar with feline grace, both guns drawn, firing warning shots that shatter empty bottles. Spike moves a split-second later, ducking behind an overturned table, pistol out as he tracks their mark. The scumbag crashes through the kitchen door. Spike follows, bullets whizzing past as Revy unloads with a wild grin. He can’t help but admire her form, deadly and beautiful, even as she’s trying to beat him to the prize. In the alley behind the bar, the punk trips, scrambling to his feet. Spike reaches him first, hand closing around the guy’s collar. “Party’s over, pal.” But Revy’s barrel presses into Spike’s cheekbone the next instant. “Back off, Cowboy. This one’s mine.” Spike doesn’t flinch, pistol still aimed at the bounty’s head. “Looks like a tie to me.” Their mark squeals, eyes darting between the two gunslingers. “P-please—” Revy cracks him over the skull with the butt of her gun. He collapses in a heap. She kicks him once for good measure. She and Spike stand over him, breathing hard, guns still raised—not at the punk, but at each other. “Damn,” Revy pants, chest heaving. “Almost fun.” Spike’s mouth curls into a slow grin. “Almost.” --- Later, the punk is trussed up in the trunk of a battered car, unconscious and drooling. Spike and Revy split the cash outside a flickering neon-lit motel, the only place open at this hour. The air is thick with humidity and tension. Revy lights another cigarette, eyeing Spike through the smoke. “So, what now?” Spike shrugs, pocketing his half of the creds. “Guess we call it a night.” She steps closer, the smell of whiskey and gunpowder clinging to her skin. “You’re not like the other bounty hunters. Too slick for your own good.” He leans against the motel’s peeling wall. “You’re not exactly what I expected either, Two Hands.” Something dark and hungry flickers in her gaze. “Maybe we should settle this. Properly.” A heartbeat passes. Then another. They end up in a cramped motel room, flickering light casting long shadows on stained sheets. Weapons drop first—his pistol, her twin Berettas—clattering to the floor as they circle each other like alley cats. Revy grabs his shirt, yanking him close, lips inches from his. “Still think this is funny, Cowboy?” Spike’s breath hitches. “Never said it was funny.” Her hand slides to his chest, feeling his heartbeat racing beneath lazy calm. “You trust me?” “Not even a little.” His voice is barely a whisper. “Good.” She presses her gun to his ribs, cold steel biting through fabric. At the same moment, he slips a hidden knife to her throat, gentle but unmistakable. A standoff, bodies pressed close, weapons drawn but eyes locked in something more dangerous than violence. Unresolved heat churns between them—fear, lust, challenge. Neither willing to surrender the upper hand, neither willing to back down. Revy’s lips curl into a feral grin. “You gonna make your move, Cowboy?” Spike smiles faintly, tragic and amused all at once. “Whatever happens, happens.” And for a long, breathless moment, they just stay like that—caught between gunplay and a kiss, trust and betrayal, both knowing this is the closest they’ll come to understanding each other. Two broken gunslingers, tangled together in the dark, daring the other to pull the trigger.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the essence of both characters from their respective anime series, creating a tense encounter that balances action, sexual tension, and the psychological barriers that define both protagonists. The writer demonstrates a strong understanding of both Spike and Revy's personalities, backgrounds, and speech patterns. The story effectively establishes the seedy setting through sensory details like the "ring of rust on Spike's lighter" and a bar that "smells like spilled whiskey and regret." These environmental touches create an appropriate noir atmosphere that fits both characters' worlds. The physical descriptions of both characters align well with their canonical appearances, particularly Revy's distinctive outfit and dragon tattoo. The dialogue is one of the strongest elements, capturing Revy's profanity-laced directness and Spike's laconic, philosophical detachment. Their verbal sparring feels authentic to both characters, with Spike's "Whatever happens, happens" philosophy contrasting nicely with Revy's more aggressive approach. The action sequence is economically written but effective, showing both characters' competence without overextending the scene. The writer balances their skills well, avoiding making either character seem superior to the other, which maintains the tension. The unresolved sexual tension builds naturally throughout the piece, culminating in the motel standoff that perfectly encapsulates their mutual attraction complicated by deep-seated trust issues. The final image of them caught between violence and desire is particularly effective and true to both characters. There are a few minor weaknesses. Some of the descriptions verge slightly on cliché ("predators circling," "feline grace"), though they remain effective. The middle section could have developed their competitive dynamic a bit more before jumping to the resolution of the bounty hunt. Additionally, while the piece does well showing their psychological barriers, it could have delved slightly deeper into their specific traumas that make intimacy difficult. Overall, this is a strong character piece that successfully merges two distinct anime worlds while maintaining the integrity of both characters. The writer clearly understands what makes both Spike and Revy tick, and creates a compelling scenario that honors their complexities.
