+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 86.2
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Letter from Calum MacLeod, Isle of Duncraig Lighthouse** **3 March 1922** Ma, Made it safe enough. The boat near tipped twice, and the landing was a cold hell, but the keeper’s cottage is dry at least. The sea’s a roaring brute out here, never quiet, like it’s angry all the time. Mr. Fraser, the senior, is gruff but fair. Says I’ll learn quick or regret it. He’s probably right. Miss your broth already. Canned meat’s no substitute. I’ll write again once I’ve settled. Your son, Calum --- **Letter from Mrs. Agnes MacLeod, Inverness** **12 March 1922** My dear Calum, Glad to hear you arrived safe. I can just see you now, soaked and grumbling. I’ve sent a parcel with oatcakes, some butter, and your wool socks. Should be with you soon. Mind your health. Your Da would be proud, and so am I. Keep busy, and the days won’t seem so long. With all my love, Ma --- **Letter from Calum** **28 March 1922** Ma, Got your parcel. Socks are a blessing. Thank you. Days are fine, work steady. Nights, though—that’s the hard part. Wind screams like a banshee, tower shudders, and it’s just us two men and the lamp. Sometimes I feel swallowed whole by darkness and sea. Fraser says it’ll pass. I’m not so sure. Your lad, Calum --- **Letter from Agnes** **5 April 1922** Dearest Calum, I wish I could send you company as easy as socks. But you’re made of tougher stuff than you think. When your Da was away fishing months on end, he’d say “The sea takes, but it gives as well.” Maybe she’s testing you. Prayers for calmer nights. Write when you can. Love, Ma --- **Letter from Calum** **20 June 1922** Ma, Summer’s here, but the fog don’t care. Last week was the worst yet. Could barely see my own boots, let alone the rocks. We nearly lost a trawler—light cut through just enough. Fraser’s nerves are shot, and I can’t blame him. Sometimes I wonder if I’m cut out for this. The quiet’s heavy. I talk to gulls now, mad as it sounds. Missing home fierce. Calum --- **Letter from Agnes** **2 July 1922** Calum, son, If talking to gulls keeps you sane, then you talk away. Loneliness is no small thing. You’ve always been stubborn. Remember when you learned to fish, how many times you dropped the line before you got it right? This is no different. You save lives out there. Never forget it. All love, Ma --- **Letter from Calum** **15 September 1922** Ma, Been rough. Fraser slipped on wet stairs last week, broke his leg bad. I had to light alone, tend him, cook, and signal for help. Took the boat two days to come—storm kept them out. Never felt so helpless. He’s gone now, replaced by McIntyre. Young, quiet. Tower feels emptier somehow. I keep seeing Fraser’s face in the lamp glass. I’m tired, Ma. Bone tired. Calum --- **Letter from Agnes** **28 September 1922** Oh my dear boy, What a burden you’ve carried. I’m proud, so proud, but I wish I could shoulder some for you. Fraser will mend, and you—you’ve proven yourself stronger than you know. Rest when you can. I’ll send more food and a blanket for winter. You’re never alone as long as I’m thinking of you. Always, Ma --- **Letter from Calum** **11 December 1922** Ma, Storms near constant now. Ice on everything. Lantern froze and took an hour to coax light back. Hands cracked and bleeding. McIntyre’s quiet turned to silence. Found him staring out the window for hours. I asked if he was well; he just shrugged. I understand. Sometimes I dream of Inverness streets, your kitchen, the smell of baking. Wake to cold stone and dark waves. But I keep the light burning. It’s all I can do. Love, Calum --- **Letter from Agnes** **23 December 1922** Calum, Your dreams of home keep you warm when the sea can’t. I’ll bake an extra loaf for you on Christmas Day, and imagine you here with us. Light the lantern and remember it means hope for every sailor caught in that blackness. For every mother, wife, and child waiting. Hold fast, son. Spring will come. With all my heart, Ma --- **Letter from Calum** **17 March 1923** Ma, Ice’s melting at last. Birds back, noisy as sin, but welcome. McIntyre left last week—couldn’t take it no more. I don’t blame him. They offered me leave, but I said no. Feels wrong to abandon the post now. Funny. Months ago, all I wanted was out. Now I feel the place in my bones. It’s harsh, aye, but it matters. I matter. I’ll be home this summer for a spell. Save some broth. Your son, Calum --- **Letter from Agnes** **2 April 1923** My dear Calum, You’ve no idea how your words warm me. I always knew you’d find your strength. I’ll make plenty of broth, and oatcakes too. Your room’s just as you left it. The sea may call you back, but for a time, you’ll be home. Can’t wait to see you, my brave boy. Love always, Ma --- **Letter from Calum** **10 July 1923** Ma, Back at the lighthouse after leave. Seeing you, sharing your table again—it healed more than I knew was broken. Now when the sea rages, I hear your voice steady in my mind. The loneliness is still there, but it’s smaller somehow. I know what I’m doing out here. I keep men safe, and I carry a bit of home with me always. Thank you for never letting go of me. All my love, Calum
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The test model has created an epistolary narrative that effectively captures the isolation and emotional journey of a Scottish lighthouse keeper through correspondence with his mother. The piece successfully adheres to the prompt's requirements, using letters as the medium and spanning several months from March 1922 to July 1923. The character of Calum is well-developed through his distinctive voice. His working-class Scottish background comes through in his diction and sentence structure without resorting to heavy-handed dialect. Phrases like "the boat near tipped twice" and "the sea's a roaring brute" establish his voice authentically. His mother Agnes also has a consistent voice that reflects her nurturing nature and wisdom. The narrative arc is well-constructed, showing Calum's initial struggle with isolation, his crisis when handling an emergency alone, and his eventual acceptance and finding meaning in his work. This transformation feels earned through the experiences described in the letters. The emotional climax comes when Calum realizes the importance of his work and his connection to the lighthouse, with a satisfying resolution in his final letter acknowledging how his mother's support helped him through. The imagery is particularly strong, with vivid descriptions of the harsh environment: "Wind screams like a banshee," "Ice on everything," and "Cold stone and dark waves." These details effectively convey the setting without becoming overwrought. The piece excels in showing emotional development through specific details rather than explicit statements. For example, Calum's growing attachment to the lighthouse is demonstrated through his decision to stay when offered leave, not through direct exposition. The correspondence format is handled skillfully, with each letter revealing just enough information to move the story forward while maintaining believability. The letters feel natural in length and content for the period and relationship. One minor weakness is that some of the emotional beats could be considered somewhat predictable—the arc from resistance to acceptance is a common one. However, the execution and specific details prevent this from feeling clichéd. The prose strikes a good balance between simplicity and eloquence, avoiding purple prose while still conveying emotion and imagery effectively. Sentences like "I keep the light burning. It's all I can do" demonstrate restraint while carrying emotional weight. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements while creating engaging characters and an emotionally satisfying narrative. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 85.9
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I spot her before she spots me, standing near the hostess stand, nervously checking her phone. Her hair’s a little messier than her profile pic, but in a good way—real, alive. I rehearse my opening line one last time, but as soon as she looks up and smiles, my brain shifts into another gear. The hacker gear. I can’t help it. I notice her phone immediately: a Pixel, small crack in the corner, no privacy screen. Glance at her lock screen notifications—Slack, Signal, some Discord pings. Interesting. Probably safe company, but who uses Signal for casual chats? She might have a story. I file that away with all the other quiet details I can’t seem to ignore. We order drinks. She’s more relaxed now, telling me about her job—QA at a gaming company—and suddenly we’re knee-deep in Magic the Gathering lore. I wasn’t expecting that. She’s animatedly describing her latest deck—Azorius control, heavy on counterspells, “because I like having the final word.” I grin. Control players are meticulous, strategic, sometimes a little ruthless. I like that. I mentally catalog the cards she drops into conversation: – **Teferi, Hero of Dominaria**: patient, grinding advantage. – **Supreme Verdict**: board wipe, reset. – **Narset, Parter of Veils**: hates card draw, likes denying options. She favors denial over brute force—definitely a control mind. I appreciate the symmetry: me, always probing systems, she, always controlling flow. I’m genuinely having fun—maybe more than I’ve had on a date in years. My mind, usually racing through exploit paths and threat models, slows just enough to enjoy this rare connection. But underneath, the familiar hum persists. Every server rack I see, every wireless signal I pass, every human interaction, I can’t help but dissect. She’s talking about her side project—an app that tracks board game stats—when her phone buzzes again. She instinctively unlocks it, and my eyes catch the pattern she draws: up, right, down, simple L-shape. Obvious, predictable. A six-year-old could shoulder-surf that. In my head, alarms blare. *Pattern unlock? Still?* And one so trivial. I bite my tongue, but the words slip out before my better judgment can catch them. “You know, anyone watching you do that could unlock your phone in two seconds.” She freezes mid-message, thumb hovering over the screen. “Excuse me?” *Shit.* Why couldn’t I have kept my mouth shut? This isn’t a pentest, this is a date. But I can’t help myself. That’s the problem with this mindset—it’s habitual, compulsive. I see vulnerabilities like blinking neon signs. I scramble. “Sorry, force of habit. I used to be a security consultant—well, hacker, actually. Reformed. My brain just… notifies me whenever I see something risky.” Her eyebrows climb. “You’re critiquing my unlock pattern?” “More like… concerned software. It’s just, like, the easiest pattern to guess. Up, right, down? A kid could—” Stop talking. She puts her phone down, face a mask now. “So, you were watching me enter my passcode?” “Not on purpose! It’s just, well, pattern unlocks are inherently insecure, and that shape is super common, so—” Abort, abort. I silence myself, mentally smacking my forehead. Way to go, genius. She looks away, suddenly fascinated by her water glass. The warmth from before has chilled. I feel like I just ran a port scan on her personal life without permission. Which, in a way, I did. I weigh my options. Apologize profusely? Change the subject? Or double down and sabotage the whole night before I screw it up worse? Classic defense: burn the bridge so no one can cross. Old habits die hard. She finally breaks the silence. “So, you were a black hat?” “I was… young, reckless. Never hurt anyone. Mostly just poked holes to see if I could. Now, I do it legally. Help companies fix themselves.” She exhales. “So, you just… see flaws everywhere?” All the time. In code, in systems, in people. Especially myself. “Yeah,” I admit quietly. “I guess it’s hard to turn off. I try, but it’s like breathing.” Her gaze softens a little. “I guess that’s better than obliviousness.” A flicker of hope. Maybe this isn’t irreparable. I decide to take a risk. “Look, I’m sorry for blurting that out. It’s a reflex, not a judgment. I’m honestly really enjoying this. You’re… you’re kind of amazing.” She smiles, tentative. “Thanks. Just… maybe save the security audit for the second date?” My chest loosens. “Deal.” We both laugh, awkward but genuine. I feel the urge to catalog this moment—an unexpected vulnerability in myself. Dinner arrives. As we eat, she tells me more about her Magic decks. She’s got a backup Selesnya tokens build—go wide, overwhelm. So she’s not just a control freak; she’s adaptable. Aggro when needed, denial when not. I file away: – **March of the Multitudes**: flood the board. – **Conclave Tribunal**: flexible removal. – **Elspeth, Sun’s Champion**: crowd control and board presence. She likes redundancy, options, backup plans. Just like a good security model. I realize I’m doing it again—profiling, analyzing, dissecting. Maybe that’s my own pattern unlock: compulsive analysis. She surprises me with a question. “So, what’s your favorite card?” I pause. Truth? “Probably **Thoughtseize**.” She laughs. “Of course it is. Rip apart their hand, see what’s hiding.” I nod. “Information is power.” She raises her glass. “To information, then.” I clink back. “And using it wisely.” The rest of dinner flows easier. I make a conscious effort to relax, to focus on her eyes instead of the restaurant’s insecure Wi-Fi, her stories instead of the insecure Bluetooth pairings I sniffed on the way in. Maybe that’s the real challenge for me now—not just finding vulnerabilities, but knowing when to leave them be. As we step outside, she hesitates. “You want to walk a bit?” “Love to.” We stroll under the city lights, close but not touching yet. I notice her unlock her phone again—same pattern—but this time, I look away, on purpose. A tiny victory, maybe. My mind still hums with threat models and exploit chains, but tonight, I’m learning a new skill: sometimes, connection means ignoring the flaws. At least for a little while. And maybe, just maybe, that’s the hardest hack of all.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative effectively captures the mindset of a reformed hacker who can't help but notice vulnerabilities everywhere. The piece successfully maintains an internal monologue throughout, as requested, and incorporates the specific scenario of a first date at a restaurant with the shared interest in Magic the Gathering. The protagonist's character is well-developed through their constant assessment of surroundings and people. The hacker mindset is convincingly portrayed through the cataloging of details, the mental "filing away" of information, and the compulsive analysis of potential security threats. The moment where they comment on the date's phone unlock pattern feels authentic to the character and creates the requested tension in the narrative. The Magic the Gathering references are integrated naturally and serve a dual purpose - establishing the shared interest that helps the date go well initially, while also providing insight into both characters through their deck preferences. The protagonist's analysis of their date's card choices as reflections of personality is particularly clever. The prose strikes a good balance between technical jargon and accessibility. Terms like "pentest," "port scan," and "shoulder-surf" establish authenticity without overwhelming the reader. The internal struggle between the protagonist's hacker instincts and their desire for human connection creates compelling tension throughout. Where the piece falls slightly short is in its resolution. While not unrealistic, the date's relatively quick forgiveness of the privacy invasion feels somewhat convenient. The ending leans toward optimism with the protagonist making "a tiny victory" by looking away from the unlock pattern, but this transformation feels a bit rushed given the deeply ingrained nature of their hacker mindset established earlier. The writing flows naturally with varied sentence structures that effectively convey the protagonist's racing thoughts. The use of bullet points and formatting to highlight the card analysis adds visual interest and reinforces the character's systematic thinking. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements while creating an engaging character study of someone caught between old habits and new desires. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5.0, Unearned Transformations: 6.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 87.2
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I’m supposed to be labeling the parts of a flower diagram right now, but instead, I’m drawing tiny caricatures of everyone at the table in the margins of my lab notebook: Leah’s high ponytail with strands always escaping, Marcus’s square glasses, and then there’s Noah — my partner for this project — with his curly hair that never quite behaves. I give him a cartoon thought bubble saying, “Photosynthesis!” because I’m hilarious, apparently. Or at least my internal monologue is. Out loud, I haven’t said more than “yeah, okay” all period. Noah’s leaning over his notes, scribbling furiously, totally focused. I should say something. Anything. “So… what do you think about the hypothesis?” Too stiff. Too formal, like I’m trying to impress the teacher instead of having an actual conversation. Maybe just “What do you think?” But then what if he asks, “About what?” and I have to clarify? Maybe I’m overcomplicating. Just ask. Open my mouth. My lips twitch, but no sound comes out. I rehearse again. “I like your idea about testing light intensity.” Too complimentary? Does it sound like I’m trying too hard? Or worse, desperate for his approval? Ugh, no. Start simple. Start neutral. “Do you want to handle the data table or should I?” That sounds reasonable. Except, he might think I’m bossy, trying to delegate right away. Why do I have to analyze every word like I’m defusing a bomb? I glance at the clock. Twenty minutes left. Plenty of time to embarrass myself. My heart thumps like everyone can hear it. I’m gripping my pencil too tight, so I loosen my hold, pretend to casually sketch another doodle — me this time, a tiny anxious blob with huge eyes and a speech bubble filled with scribbles instead of words. Story of my life. Noah looks up suddenly. Eye contact. Abort mission! But I force myself to hold his gaze for a second so I don’t seem rude. He smiles, kind of crooked, and I nearly melt into my chair. I should smile back. Did I smile? I think I did. Was it weird? Too big? Too hesitant? Does he think I’m a freak? He says, “Um, do you think we should test different color filters too?” I nod quickly. “Yeah. That’s… good.” Ugh, so eloquent. My internal vocabulary is like a thesaurus and all I can manage out loud is “good.” Why can’t I say, “Great idea — it’d be interesting to see how different wavelengths affect photosynthesis rates”? Because that sounds rehearsed, that’s why. Because I’m terrified of sounding like a know-it-all or, worse, like I’m trying to impress him. Which I totally am, but no way does he need to know that. I doodle a little prism with a rainbow pouring out. Maybe if I focus on the art, I can quiet my brain. He’s still waiting. Say something else. “We can, um, split up the filters testing and the data recording if you want?” My voice comes out softer than I intended, but at least it’s there. He nods. “Cool.” His voice is effortless, casual. Why can’t I be like that? The silence grows heavy again, but not the comfortable kind. I flip a page in my notebook, pretending to check my notes, but really just avoiding his eyes. Am I blinking too much? Is my face red? Probably. I always blush when I’m nervous. What if he notices? He’ll think I’m weird. Or that I have a crush on him, which… I do. But he can’t know that. I’d die. I imagine saying, “You’re really good at this,” casually praising him. But then I picture him thinking I’m flirting, which I guess I sort of would be, but what if he’s not interested? Or worse, what if he tells everyone? No. Too risky. Or maybe I ask, “Do you like science?” Too generic. Obviously, he does — he’s in the advanced class. “What’s your favorite experiment we’ve done so far?” No, too much like an interview. Why am I like this? My brain runs through a hundred scenarios: I say something stupid, he laughs at me. I say something smart, he thinks I’m a show-off. I say nothing, and he thinks I’m boring. Lose-lose-lose. I glance over at Leah and Marcus. They’re joking about something, leaning close, laughing easily. Why can’t I be like that? My thoughts are so clear in my head, witty and articulate, but they get stuck somewhere between my brain and my mouth, tangled up in nerves. Out loud I’m all ums and half-sentences. Inside, I’m giving TED Talks. I draw tiny speech bubbles for Leah and Marcus, filled with ha-ha-ha’s. Then I add one for myself, just ellipses. Perfect. Noah’s tapping his pen on the table. I realize I’ve been silent again for way too long. Say something. Anything. “So, um, do you think plants actually grow better under red light?” There. A real question. Not too weird. “Yeah, I read somewhere that red wavelengths are best for photosynthesis,” he says, brightening. “But I guess it depends on the plant.” See? Was that so hard? My internal critic rolls her eyes. Yes, actually, it was. I nod, jotting down a fake note to look busy. Should I add, “That’s interesting,” or is that redundant? Maybe just smile and make eye contact. I try, but my cheeks heat up again. I probably look like a tomato. Great. What if he thinks my blushing means I’m into him? Which I am. But again: he can’t know. I’d rather crawl under the table. I imagine telling him, “I think you’re really smart.” Or, “You’re funny.” Or, the ultimate nightmare: “I like you.” And immediately want to evaporate. No way. I can’t even say “Nice idea” without worrying it sounds desperate. Confessing feelings? Impossible. My pencil moves automatically, sketching a tiny superhero with an N on his chest — Noah, Plant Guy. Then a scribble of me, hiding behind a giant leaf. Accurate. What do normal people say next? Compliment? Joke? Share a random fact? I have all these ideas swirling but no safe way to get them out. Every option feels risky. What if my voice cracks? Or I say something dumb? Or my hands shake and he notices? Or I forget words mid-sentence? Ugh. He leans closer to look at my notes. “Wow, your sketches are really cool.” My stomach flips. Compliment — danger zone! Be cool. Just say thanks. “Oh, um, thanks.” Did that sound weird? Too quiet? Too quick? Should I have said more? Maybe, “I like drawing.” Or, “Just a habit.” No, that sounds dismissive. Now it’s too late, I missed my chance. He’s still smiling. Maybe it was okay. Breathe. I doodle a tiny heart behind one of the flowers. Immediately erase it. Don’t be obvious. We start organizing the data table. I focus on neat lines and legible numbers, because numbers don’t judge me. Words do. In my head, I’m composing perfect conversations we could have, where I’m charming and witty and confident, and he laughs at my jokes and maybe even… likes me back. But in real life, I’m just a nervous mess, overanalyzing every glance and syllable, terrified of saying too much or too little. Group work is almost over. I glance at the clock. Five minutes. Relief and disappointment mix in my chest. Maybe next time, I’ll say more. Maybe next time, I won’t get so tangled up inside. Maybe. For now, I draw a tiny doodle of me with a speech bubble finally saying, “Hi.” It’s a start.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the internal monologue of an 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on her science project partner. The piece excels at portraying the gap between her articulate internal voice and her stilted external communication, which was a key requirement of the prompt. The protagonist's constant second-guessing and overthinking is rendered with impressive psychological realism. Her internal rehearsals of potential conversations, followed by immediate self-criticism, effectively convey the exhausting mental process of someone with social anxiety. Lines like "Why do I have to analyze every word like I'm defusing a bomb?" succinctly capture her experience. The narrative uses the science project setting well, incorporating relevant details about photosynthesis and experimental design that ground the story in its context. The protagonist's habit of doodling serves multiple purposes: it shows her artistic side, provides a coping mechanism for her anxiety, and offers visual metaphors for her emotional state. The prose flows naturally, with sentence structures that vary between longer analytical thoughts and shorter, more panicked reactions. This creates a rhythm that mimics the character's thought patterns. The writing maintains a consistent voice throughout—intelligent but self-conscious, with the vocabulary and concerns appropriate for a bright 8th grader. The character's emotional complexity is well-developed. We see her frustration with herself, her admiration for Noah, her envy of peers who communicate easily, and her simultaneous desire to connect and fear of rejection. The narrative avoids simplistic characterization by showing her awareness of her own contradictions. The piece doesn't rely on dramatic external events but instead creates tension through the protagonist's internal struggle. This approach is perfect for the prompt's focus on internal monologue. The minimal dialogue that does appear serves to highlight the contrast between her rich inner life and sparse verbal expression. The ending strikes an appropriate balance—not resolving her anxiety unrealistically, but offering a small note of hope with her drawing of herself finally saying "Hi." This modest aspiration feels true to the character and avoids an incongruent positive resolution. Some minor weaknesses include occasional repetition of the same anxious thoughts, which while realistic, could be varied more to deepen our understanding of the character. The piece could also benefit from more specific sensory details about the classroom environment to ground the reader more firmly in the scene. Overall, this is an impressive character study that fulfills the prompt requirements while creating a sympathetic, believable protagonist whose internal struggles will resonate with many readers. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 86.8
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I stare at my reflection, eyes ringed and raw, fingers trembling as I fumble with the collar of my shirt. I tell myself it’s just lunch, just meeting Jamie, but that’s a joke—I know it’s so much more. It’s the day everything could fall apart, the moment they finally realize I’m too much, too needy, too broken, and leave. The dull thump of my neighbor’s television seeps through the wall—some sitcom laughter muffled and distant, so normal, so oblivious. I wish I could drown out my own thoughts that easily. They’ve been distant lately, Jamie. Fewer texts, longer gaps. I keep replaying the last time we saw each other, trying to pinpoint where I messed up. Did I say something off? Was I too clingy? I rehearse what they’re probably going to say today: “I need space,” or worse, “I just can’t do this anymore.” I see their face, kind but hesitant, struggling to find gentle words for rejection. I brace myself for it, over and over. In my head, I craft my responses—sometimes defensive, sometimes cold. “Oh, so now you’re just going to disappear like everyone else?” I imagine myself snapping. Or maybe I’ll plead: “Please, don’t leave me. I’m sorry, I can be better.” Then I get angry at myself for even imagining begging. Pathetic. I decide maybe I should just cut them off first. “You know what? Forget it. I don’t need someone who can’t handle me.” Better to leave before I’m left behind. But then, another voice, softer, creeps in—what if I’m wrong? What if they’ve just been busy? What if I’m inventing problems that don’t exist? I’ve done that before. I know I do it. For half a breath, I see the pattern, clear as day, the way I spin harmless things into looming disasters. But then the doubt rushes back in, louder, more convincing. Sure, maybe I’m overreacting, but what if this time I’m not? What if ignoring these signs means I get blindsided later, gutted by their abandonment? No, better to stay alert, to armor up with resentment before the blow lands. I picture how they’ll avoid my eyes, fumble for excuses. Maybe they’ll call me “intense” again. That word stings every time. Makes me feel like a freak. I start constructing a list of their flaws, reasons why I shouldn’t care if they leave. They’re emotionally unavailable. Selfish. Just like everyone else. I cling to that anger because it’s safer than the desperation underneath. I check my phone for the tenth time. Still no new message. Running late, or maybe they’re standing me up. I imagine them texting a friend right now: “Ugh, I have to deal with them again.” Or worse, laughing about me afterwards. My stomach twists. Do they pity me? Are they embarrassed by me? Is that why they’ve been distant? Suddenly, a new wave of humiliation crashes over me—god, if they do dump me, will they tell everyone I’m crazy? Is that the story they’ll spread? I rehearse defending myself against invisible accusations. “I’m not crazy, I just feel things more deeply.” Or maybe I’ll own it, use it as a shield: “Yeah, I’m intense, at least I’m real, unlike you.” The words feel hollow even in my head. I step outside, the air thick and heavy. As I walk to the café, the noise of the city blurs into the background hum, like the muffled TV next door—a world I’m not quite part of. Each footstep echoes with dread. I almost turn back twice, convinced I’m walking into my own humiliation. But then I see Jamie already waiting by the window, waving when they spot me, smile bright and easy. For a second, my chest warms. Relief floods in so fast it almost makes me dizzy. Maybe they’re happy to see me. Maybe they haven’t changed their mind. I cling to that fragile hope as I walk in. “Hey, you,” Jamie says, pulling me into a hug. It feels real, solid. I breathe in the scent of their shampoo, the press of their body, and for a moment I want to cry from the sheer relief of being wanted. But then the doubt slinks back in. Are they just good at pretending? Are they hugging me because they feel guilty? Pity me? Is this all one last kindness before they cut me loose? I scan their face for signs—a flicker of annoyance, a forced smile. I find none, but that doesn’t stop me from imagining them there anyway. We sit, order coffee. Jamie reaches across the table, fingers brushing mine. “I’ve missed you,” they say softly. The words hit me like sunlight on skin gone cold. I want to believe them so badly it hurts. I swallow hard, nod, smile weakly. But then I think: If they missed me, why the distance? Why the slow replies? Maybe they’re just saying what I want to hear. Maybe they’re lying to keep the peace. Maybe they’re already halfway out the door. I rehearse calling them out. “If you really missed me, why have you been avoiding me?” I imagine the confrontation escalating, their defenses rising, their face hardening. I see myself storming out, righteous and furious, before they get the chance to leave me. But I don’t say it. I just nod, trying to lock this moment away, this fleeting warmth, knowing it could vanish any second. Jamie leans in, eyes gentle. “Sorry I’ve been a little off. Work’s been hell. I didn’t mean to make you feel neglected.” My heart squeezes. I want to believe it’s true—that it wasn’t about me at all. Part of me does, and I feel the desperate urge to melt into that reassurance, to trust it completely. And yet, another part whispers, liar. Excuses. They’re just softening the blow, buying time until they ghost me for good. I look down, nails digging into my palm under the table. I know this isn’t fair. I catch a glimpse of it—that I’m punishing them for crimes they haven’t committed, reliving old betrayals in new skin. But the fear is so loud, so convincing. I almost tell them all of this, but I swallow it back. Too risky. What if honesty just drives them away faster? Jamie squeezes my hand. “You okay?” I nod, forcing a smile. “Yeah.” My voice sounds thin, foreign. I want to say, “Please don’t leave me.” I want to say, “I’m terrified.” Instead, I ask, “Are we… good?” They smile softly. “Of course we are.” Warmth blooms again. I want to sink into it, wrap it around me like armor. For a moment, I almost believe in us. Almost. But then the doubts creep back, whispering that I’m a fool for trusting so easily, that I’m setting myself up for heartbreak. I brace myself, rehearsing every possible way this could end, every terrible thing they might secretly think of me. Better to be ready, I tell myself. Better to hurt now than later. Through it all, I cling to the fragile hope of their love, desperate and suspicious at once. The muffled TV laughter next door goes on and on, oblivious. I wonder what it’s like to live in that simple world, where love is just love—not a battlefield of imagined betrayals and rehearsed rejections. Where trust comes easy, and you’re not always preparing for the worst. Maybe one day. But not today.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative effectively captures the internal experience of someone with borderline personality disorder (BPD), particularly the characteristic fear of abandonment and tendency to catastrophize. The piece excels at depicting the protagonist's cognitive distortions as they prepare to meet Jamie, cycling between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments. The narrative successfully portrays the protagonist's internal monologue, showing how they construct elaborate scenarios of rejection despite contrary evidence. The writing effectively demonstrates the cognitive dissonance experienced—moments of recognition ("For half a breath, I see the pattern, clear as day") quickly overwhelmed by the compelling nature of catastrophic thinking. This selective self-awareness is portrayed convincingly. The prose is tightly focused on the protagonist's inner experience, with physical details serving to ground the narrative in reality while maintaining the claustrophobic feeling of being trapped in one's thoughts. Sentences like "I stare at my reflection, eyes ringed and raw, fingers trembling as I fumble with the collar of my shirt" effectively establish both the physical setting and emotional state. The narrative skillfully contrasts the protagonist's catastrophizing with Jamie's actual warm behavior. When Jamie hugs them, says "I've missed you," and explains their distance was due to work, we see the protagonist's momentary relief quickly undermined by doubt: "But then the doubt slinks back in. Are they just good at pretending?" This pattern of validation immediately questioned perfectly captures the prompt's requirements. The piece maintains a consistent voice throughout, with the internal monologue feeling authentic to someone experiencing BPD symptoms. The writing avoids clinical language while accurately depicting the condition's emotional reality. The protagonist's shifting between anger, fear, hope, and suspicion feels organic rather than contrived. Where the piece could be stronger is in varying its rhythm more. The pattern of hope-doubt-catastrophize becomes somewhat predictable by the end. While this repetition accurately reflects the experience of BPD, some variation in the intensity or manifestation of these thoughts could have added more texture. The ending effectively avoids both unrealistic transformation and complete despair, landing on a note that acknowledges both the protagonist's ongoing struggle and their awareness of it: "Through it all, I cling to the fragile hope of their love, desperate and suspicious at once." This feels true to the condition while maintaining narrative integrity. Overall, this is a strong piece that demonstrates deep understanding of BPD's emotional landscape while creating a compelling narrative that engages the reader's empathy without romanticizing mental illness. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Physical-spatial: Blood Debt — Score: 82.2
Prompt:
"Blood Debt" Write a vivid third-person narrative depicting an unsanctioned underground duel between two talented but hot-headed martial artists. Their schools have been embroiled in a generations-old rivalry, and despite strict prohibitions from their masters, these two younger fighters arrange a secret confrontation fueled by personal pride and simmering animosity. - **One fighter** represents **Jigen-ryū**, a traditional, aggressive style practiced historically by elite samurai clans. Its practitioners emphasize explosive offense, decisive strikes, and overwhelming speed. Known historically for their arrogance and disdain toward outsiders, practitioners consider their art superior and untouchable. - **The opposing fighter** employs a form of historical **Piguaquan**, a Chinese martial art traditionally practiced by commoners, bodyguards, and street fighters. This style emphasizes whipping, circular strikes, rapid footwork, unpredictable angles of attack, and evasive maneuvers. Practitioners often come from lower social classes and view the traditional elite as pretentious and detached from true combat effectiveness. The fight takes place in the crumbling ruins of an abandoned temple, now functioning as a hidden arena for illicit duels. Passionate supporters from both factions surround them, wagering money, pride, and reputation on the outcome. **Essential Instructions:** Maintain absolute physical coherence throughout—clearly track fighters' positions relative to each other and their environment. Precisely depict strikes, counters, momentum shifts, and spatial dynamics, allowing readers to clearly visualize the mechanics and choreography of the fight at every moment. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A faint, acrid scent of incense and mildew hangs in the air of the ruined temple, its once-sacred pillars now fractured and mottled with creeping moss. Moonlight seeps through broken rafters, illuminating a crude circle where two figures face one another, eyes burning with familial hatred and personal pride. Crumbling statues leer from the shadows as the crowd presses tight along the edges, their eager whispers swallowed by the oppressive silence before the storm. The Jigen-ryū fighter, Ryunosuke, stands poised near a toppled altar. His feet are shoulder-width apart, knees slightly bent, right hand gripping the hilt of a wooden bokken honed razor-sharp for this illicit duel. His torso coils like a spring, ready to unleash the explosive offense his clan is infamous for. Moonlight glints off his sweat-slicked face, jaw clenched in arrogant disdain. Opposite him, Jian, the Piguaquan stylist, shifts his weight lightly near a cracked stone step. Barehanded, he circles with fluid, rolling steps, his arms loose and whipping gently through the air like willow branches testing the breeze. His stance is low and mobile, body coiled to slip or redirect, eyes constantly tracking Ryunosuke’s every twitch. Between them, a shallow stream of water trickles through a crack in the floor, pooling then sliding onward. The uneven slick stones threaten betrayal with every step, adding a cruel edge of uncertainty. A guttural shout shatters the silence. Ryunosuke lunges first, channeling generations of elite aggression. His entire frame surges forward in a blindingly fast sprint—three bounding steps launching him across the gap. As he closes in, he raises the bokken high in a diagonal arc, hips snapping, intent on a decisive, skull-cracking blow from Ryū’s signature kiriotoshi strike. But Jian is already moving. He pivots sharply to his left, outside the arc of the descending blade, water splashing under his quick sidestep. His right arm loops in a wide, circular path, the heel of his palm snapping toward Ryunosuke’s exposed ribs just beneath the armpit. The strike lands with a wet thud, the force amplified by the whip-like rotation of his waist and shoulder. Ryunosuke grunts, pain flaring but discipline overriding it. He rotates his torso into the blow, lessening the impact, and instantly retracts his bokken with a swift backhand slash aimed at Jian’s temple. Jian ducks under it, knees bending deeply, palms brushing the slick floor for balance. He then rolls forward, slipping beneath Ryunosuke’s extended right arm, and pops up behind him, twisting nimbly on the balls of his feet. Crowd gasps echo off ancient walls as Jian’s momentum carries him into a spinning backfist aimed at the base of Ryunosuke’s skull. But Ryunosuke pivots sharply on his left foot, his back momentarily exposed but now guarded by the swift turn. The fist grazes his shoulder instead, and he counters with a brutal, upward thrust of the bokken’s tip toward Jian’s solar plexus. Jian’s torso snaps backward, spine arching away from the wooden point. He plants his right foot just outside the stream to prevent slipping and swings his left arm in a circular downward arc, deflecting the thrust to the side with the back of his forearm. The redirected bokken slides past his ribs, missing by inches. Ryunosuke snarls, pressing the attack. He steps across the stream with his right foot, boot skidding slightly on the slick stones. He corrects instantly, channeling imbalance into a low, sweeping cut aimed at Jian’s legs, intending to cripple or topple him. Jian hops backward, water splashing from beneath his heels. Landing just beyond the bokken’s reach, he circles right, forcing Ryunosuke to turn with him. Jian’s arms whip out again, left hand feinting high, right arm looping down in a heavy, circular chop toward Ryunosuke’s lead shoulder. Ryunosuke raises his bokken horizontally, intercepting Jian’s descending forearm with a hollow crack of wood on bone. The block halts Jian’s strike but also exposes Ryunosuke’s midsection for a split second. Jian seizes the opportunity, snapping his left fist into Ryunosuke’s abdomen with a quick, piston-like jab, forcing a grunt from deep within his chest. Staggering back a step, Ryunosuke’s heel lands in the shallow water, slipping outward. He drops low instinctively, knee nearly touching the stones to stabilize. From this crouch, he explodes upward with a vicious rising slash, aiming for Jian’s chin. Jian sways backward, the tip of the bokken slicing a hair’s breadth before his nose. As Ryunosuke overextends, Jian pivots sharply around Ryunosuke’s right side, inside the arc of the weapon. He plants his left foot outside the stream, then drives his right elbow into Ryunosuke’s ribs again in a tight, close-range strike. Ryunosuke absorbs the blow with a grimace, swinging his bokken backhanded behind him, catching Jian’s thigh with a glancing blow that forces Jian to disengage. Jian hops sideways onto drier ground, circling warily. Their chests heave in unison, sweat mingling with temple dust and moon shadows. The crowd’s tension crackles as wagers shift with every exchange. Ryunosuke shifts tactics, feinting a forward rush but stopping short. Jian falls for the bait, stepping forward to counter, but Ryunosuke suddenly lunges with a lightning-fast thrust instead of another sweeping cut. The bokken’s point drives toward Jian’s sternum. At the last instant, Jian twists his torso sideways, the wooden blade scraping along his ribs but failing to penetrate cleanly. He traps the bokken beneath his right arm, clamping it tight. Before Ryunosuke can wrench it free, Jian’s left hand loops up and over in a downward hammer fist, smashing into Ryunosuke’s collarbone. Wooden crack meets bone crack. Ryunosuke’s left shoulder buckles, momentarily numbing his grip. Jian releases the trap, spinning away with the bokken’s momentum, then lashes out with a sweeping back kick aimed at Ryunosuke’s knee. The kick connects, and Ryunosuke staggers sideways, boot slipping again in the water. But Ryunosuke’s spirit flares brighter amid the pain. He plants his bokken tip on the ground like a staff, stabilizing himself. With a snarl, he vaults forward in a desperate, explosive leap, swinging the bokken in a final diagonal arc meant to end this with one stroke. Jian sidesteps again, just barely avoiding the deadly arc, feeling the displaced air graze his cheek. As Ryunosuke lands off-balance, Jian lashes a rapid series of whipping strikes: right palm to temple, left chop to neck, spinning elbow toward the jaw. Each blow connects, driving Ryunosuke backward, disoriented and bleeding from the mouth. His footing lost, Ryunosuke’s heel strikes the stream again. This time he slips hard, crashing onto his back amid cold water and shattered tiles. The bokken clatters from his numb fingers, skidding out of reach. Jian advances cautiously, circling around Ryunosuke’s prone form, arms raised and ready. Ryunosuke struggles to rise, pride burning hotter than pain, but his limbs betray him, trembling and slow. A hush falls over the crowd as Jian plants his foot firmly on Ryunosuke’s chest, pinning him. For a heartbeat, their eyes lock—rage, shame, triumph, and exhaustion swirling between them. Jian steps back, leaving Ryunosuke gasping amid the stream. The blood debt between their schools remains unpaid, yet a new chapter is written in secret moonlight, beneath the ruined temple where pride and hatred clash as fiercely as any blade.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This martial arts narrative successfully creates a vivid, physically coherent fight scene between two contrasting fighters. The author establishes the setting effectively with sensory details of the abandoned temple, creating an atmospheric backdrop for the duel. The physical positioning and movements of both fighters are meticulously tracked throughout, allowing readers to visualize the fight's choreography with precision. The narrative excels in technical descriptions of martial arts techniques. The Jigen-ryū fighter's explosive, decisive strikes contrast well with the Piguaquan practitioner's circular, whipping movements. Each fighter's techniques remain true to their respective styles throughout the encounter. The author demonstrates strong knowledge of martial arts terminology and mechanics, describing not just the attacks but the physics behind them—how weight shifts, how momentum transfers, and how balance is maintained or lost. The environmental element of the stream running through the temple floor is cleverly incorporated as a tactical consideration that affects the fighters' footing. This adds tension and realism to the fight, as Ryunosuke repeatedly slips on the wet stones, ultimately contributing to his defeat. Character-wise, the piece establishes the fighters' personalities primarily through their fighting styles rather than extensive backstory. Ryunosuke embodies the arrogance of the elite samurai tradition, while Jian represents the resourceful adaptability of the common fighter. However, their characterization remains somewhat surface-level, focused more on their physical actions than their internal experiences. The prose is generally strong, with varied sentence structures and vivid action verbs that create a sense of momentum. Occasionally, the writing becomes slightly overwrought with metaphors like "coils like a spring" or "arms loose and whipping gently through the air like willow branches," but these instances are balanced by crisp, direct descriptions of combat. The ending avoids a simplistic resolution, acknowledging that while this duel has concluded, the larger conflict between the schools remains unresolved. This adds depth to what might otherwise be a straightforward fight scene. The narrative's primary weakness is that it occasionally prioritizes technical precision over emotional engagement. While we understand the fighters' pride and the stakes of their rivalry, we don't deeply feel their personal motivations or the weight of the generations-old conflict they're perpetuating. The crowd's reactions are mentioned but not developed in a way that amplifies the tension. Overall, this is a technically accomplished martial arts narrative that excels in physical coherence and fight choreography while maintaining thematic consistency with the prompt's requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 13 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 14.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 13.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Physical-spatial: Breaking Formation — Score: 86.8
Prompt:
**"Breaking Formation"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a street dancer from a rough neighborhood who's won a scholarship to an elite K-pop training academy in Seoul. Desperately out of place culturally and technically, they struggle with a militaristically precise choreography that contradicts everything about their improvisational background. The punishing rehearsal takes place under a famous instructor known for breaking students to remake them, who sees potential in the narrator's raw talent but not their attitude. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—each dance move, position shift, and spatial relationship must be tracked with precision throughout the studio. Paint an exceptionally vivid kinetic picture through descriptions that capture not just movement but the contrast between the narrator's fluid, expressive style and the mechanical precision demanded. Their internal monologue should reveal culture shock, class anxiety, and the threatening realization that success here might mean losing their authentic movement voice. Include technical terminology that highlights the collision of street and commercial styles, moments when muscle memory betrays them, and a crucial decision point about whether to conform or rebel. Physical clarity is essential—readers must be able to visualize exactly how bodies move through space, how rhythms align or clash, and how the protagonist's body struggles against unfamiliar discipline. 1000 words.
Model Output:
My sneakers squeak against the polished marley floor, an unfamiliar slickness compared to the battered concrete of my block. The mirrored walls reflect a regiment of trainees in matching monochrome sweats, all lined up in deadly symmetry like toy soldiers. Their limbs snap clean angles on the downbeat, hitting every iso and lock in perfect synchrony. I’m the jagged edge in this smooth machine. Our instructor stands in front, barely five feet but larger than life, wielding a lacquered black hand fan like a general’s baton. When she snaps it open, the room falls silent. When it cracks shut, time stops. Right now, it hovers half-open as she watches us re-run the chorus combo for the hundredth time. My chest heaves. Sweat stings my eyes. I force my feet into the opening step—a sharp diagonal slide with the right foot, left foot crossing tight behind, then weight shift to prep for a double-wave ripple through the chest and arms. They hit it like clockwork, every ribcage expansion identical, wrists flicking on cue, elbows frozen midair before slicing down with robotic precision. Me? My chest wave rolls out too slow, hips starting to follow because that’s what my freestyle instincts demand—fluidity, groove, a story in the curve of my spine. But here, that softness is a sin. I try to cut it short, but the momentum betrays me, and instead of a clean stop, my upper torso keeps rolling past the count. My reflection looks like a worn-out vinyl skipping on a smooth track. SNAP. The fan cracks shut. “Again,” she says, eyes boring into me. “You’re leaking all over the beat. Contain.” I swallow hard. Contain? Back home, dance was explosion and flow—popping, krumping, break footwork sprawling across the sidewalk, all about feeling the music and letting it possess you. Here, it’s about control, about every muscle obeying the metronome. We reset. Eight counts. I see the grid in my mind—a tight box around my body, lines I’m supposed to stick to. The intro hits: One—sharp step right, toes pointed in, knee locked. Two—cross left behind, heel lifted to create that triangular silhouette. Three—hips snap front, pelvis tucked. Four—arms flick up, elbows at ninety, hands slicing like blades. Five-six—pop the chest twice, quick contractions like a heartbeat. Seven-eight—retract arms, feet together, ready for the next phrase. I try to hit it all, but muscle memory trips me up. On the chest pops, my shoulders want to roll, adding bounce and groove. Instead, I clamp my torso tight, fighting the urge to melt into the beat. My body rebels in micro-tremors. The others? They’re like clones, moving in lockstep, no soul but perfect. The next section demands a ripple wave down the arms—shoulder to elbow to wrist, then fingers flick outward. I can do this in my sleep, but the academy way is different. They want it hyper-controlled, no lag, no extra flair. I’m used to exaggerating the wave, letting it roll back and forth with bounce and attitude, almost taunting the crowd. Now, I try to shut that voice off and compress the movement, but it feels like choking down a scream. Our lines shift—two steps to the diagonal right, quick pivot, then a staggered formation with me falling behind a girl in front. The spatial change is razor-sharp, no room for error. I nearly clip her heel as I misjudge the pivot speed, stumbling half a beat late. The mirror shows a ripple of annoyance on her face, even as she keeps perfect time. SNAP. The fan again. “Sloppy. Foot placement precise, spacing consistent. You—” her gaze pins me, “—stop dragging the groove behind you. Hit.” My heart pounds, humiliation burning hotter than sweat. Back home, dragging the groove was *the point*. Stretching time, playing with the beat, bending it until people hollered. Here, it’s a crime. We run it again. I clamp down on the urge to milk the moves, forcing sharp stops. My thighs quiver from the constant tension. The counts blur: One-two—lockstep, Three-four—control, Five-six—contract, Seven-eight—freeze. I’m a puppet with too-tight strings. Halfway through, the music breaks into a half-time bridge. Their bodies shift instantly—shoulders squared, core tight, foot slide perfectly timed with the snare. I hesitate a split second too long, muscles wanting to ride the slowed rhythm, add bounce, sink into it. Instead, I jerk into the position late. The ripple of the group breaks, fracture centered on me. SNAP. Her voice is low but lethal. “You dance like you’re alone in an alley, not on a stage with twelve others. Discipline.” I bite back a retort. Because that’s exactly what I am—a kid from the alley, not a polished idol. My style is raw, improvisational—freestyle footwork, explosive krumps, smooth glides that break rules. Here, every rule is sacred. We start again. Diagonal slide. Cross behind. Weight shift. Ripple. Pop-pop. Wave. Pivot. Step. Freeze. My mind counts even as my body rebels. I force my chest wave into a mechanical pulse, kill the hip swing, lock my arms into perfect angles. I feel like I’m suffocating under the weight of precision, the groove dying in my veins. On the next bridge, something snaps inside. Do I keep killing what makes me *me*? Or do I let that rawness bleed out, even if it means breaking formation? Music hits. One. Two. Three. I choose rebellion. On the ripple, I exaggerate the wave—shoulder surging, elbow softening, wrist flicking late, fingers trailing like smoke. The beat hits half-time, and instead of snapping tight, I let my hips sink into it, rolling slow, grounding the groove. I bounce the chest pop, adding a bassline swagger, feet gliding just a hair past the mark. Around me, the formation stutters. The mirror shows a ripple of discord—my body moving like water while theirs stay frozen steel. I see the instructor’s eyes narrow, lips pressing thin. SNAP. Dead silence. She steps toward me, fan pointed like a dagger. “You think you know better?” I meet her gaze, chest still heaving, sweat dripping from my chin. “No,” I say quietly, “but I know *me*.” A long pause. Then, surprisingly, the faintest hint of a smile. “Again,” she says. “This time—show me both.” And cracks the fan open. I breathe deep. The music restarts. Feet planted, chest coiled, heart pounding. Somewhere between the machine and the street, I start again—searching for my own rhythm inside theirs.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative effectively captures the cultural and technical clash between street dance and K-pop training. The piece excels in its physical descriptions, maintaining spatial coherence throughout the dance sequence while contrasting the narrator's fluid style with the rigid precision demanded by the academy. The physical descriptions are particularly strong. The writer uses specific dance terminology (iso, lock, wave, pop) and describes movements with precision: "a sharp diagonal slide with the right foot, left foot crossing tight behind, then weight shift to prep for a double-wave ripple through the chest and arms." These details create a vivid kinetic picture that allows readers to visualize the choreography. The internal monologue successfully conveys the protagonist's culture shock and anxiety. Lines like "Back home, dance was explosion and flow" contrasted with "Here, it's about control" effectively highlight the philosophical differences between street dance and K-pop training. The protagonist's struggle is palpable through descriptions of physical discomfort: "My thighs quiver from the constant tension" and emotional distress: "humiliation burning hotter than sweat." The narrative maintains a consistent voice throughout, using language that feels authentic to a street dancer. The instructor is well-characterized through minimal but effective details: "barely five feet but larger than life, wielding a lacquered black hand fan like a general's baton." The SNAP of her fan becomes a powerful motif that punctuates the narrative and creates tension. The decision point comes naturally at the climax when the protagonist chooses to rebel rather than conform. This moment feels earned through the building frustration described throughout the piece. The instructor's surprising response adds complexity to her character, suggesting she might value authenticity alongside precision. While the prose is generally strong, there are moments where it becomes slightly repetitive in structure, particularly in the sections breaking down the counts. The ending, while offering a glimmer of hope and resolution, feels slightly rushed and perhaps too positive given the severity of the cultural clash established throughout. Overall, this is a compelling narrative that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements. It creates a vivid physical world, explores cultural and class tensions, and presents a protagonist at a genuine crossroads between authenticity and conformity. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ Gothic-fantasy-humour: Court of the Dreaming — Score: 81.6
Prompt:
Court of the Dreaming: Territorial Dream Dispute. Write a dark fantasy scene with comedic elements set in the Courts of Dream where a case is being heard to determine ownership of a contested dreamscape. Mora, the Slavic nightmare spirit who sits on sleepers' chests causing paralysis and terror, has recently invaded and subverted a carefully crafted recurring dream of a schoolboy, Max. The dream originally featured the boy lying in a field of wildflowers with his crush, always culminating in a muddled almost-kiss and a pleasant confusion of emotions. This dream was the meticulous work of "First Love" (a rosy-cheeked, slightly bashful entity who crafts formative romantic experiences). However, Mora has recently infiltrated the dreamscape, transforming the scene so that when the girl playfully mounts the boy, she morphs into a terrifying yet somehow still confusingly attractive vision who proceeds to sit on his chest and feed on his breath. Mora's defense largely consists of the practical argument that "a girl's gotta eat too, you know?" Write this scene as it unfolds in the courtroom of the Dreaming, with Dream's demeanour, typically impenetrable, betraying a sense of irritation at having to adjudicate such matters. The comedy should derive from the farcical situation, familiar elements of courtroom drama intersecting with the fantastical world of the Dreaming, and the droll portrayal of the characters and their interactions. The humor should be dark and understated throughout. Dream is tempted to some mischief in the resolution of the case. Use descriptives sparingly when setting scene. Write for readability & engagement. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Court of the Dreaming was in session, and as usual, it looked like a particularly grandiose hallucination framed by shadows and starlight. Great pillars shimmered with impossible geometries; the air itself rippled with whispers of half-remembered lullabies and primal fears. Dream of the Endless sat atop his throne, carved from obsidian darker than night, his pallor pale as old bone and eyes like twin vortexes of eternity. Today, even his inscrutable calm seemed to fray. Cases like these — petty squabbles over nightmares and adolescent fancies — tested the patience of an immortal lord. Standing below, the bailiff’s voice thundered ominously: “CALLING... FURST LOOOF!” First Love shuffled forward, cheeks pink as apple blossoms, wringing his hands nervously, his freckles shimmering faintly. Even his aura smelled faintly of nervous sweat and crushed violets, the scent of young hearts in bloom. “And... MORA, THE NIGHTMARE!” A shadow slithered across the floor, coalescing into the form of a woman both beautiful and terrifying. Dark hair tangled around a face that flickered between alluring and skull-like, eyes bright with hunger. Mora smiled lazily, revealing teeth that were far too sharp. Dream’s voice was soft but carried the weight of falling worlds. “Begin.” First Love straightened, voice trembling with righteous indignation. “Your lordship, I crafted young Max’s recurring dream with utmost care: a sunlit meadow, youthful longing, an innocent almost-kiss — the confusion that stays sweet in waking. It was *perfect*. Until *she*—” he nodded accusingly at Mora “—corrupted it into a horror show!” Mora yawned extravagantly. “Oh please. I didn’t *corrupt* anything. I just... repurposed it.” First Love spluttered. “Repurposed? You turned his first crush into a wheezing paralysis nightmare! Instead of butterflies, he wakes up choking!” Mora’s lip curled, half amused, half feral. “A girl’s gotta eat too, you know? Breath don’t harvest itself. Besides, the line between terror and desire is *very* thin.” She winked at Dream, who remained impassive, though perhaps his eye twitched just a fraction. First Love clutched at his chest. “Your grace, this is an outrage! The boy will never look at a girl the same again. He’ll be traumatized!” Mora laughed, low and dark. “Or maybe he’ll develop very interesting tastes. Who are *we* to judge kink?” The courtroom murmured, echoes of nightmares and love-sick longing mingling in the air. A jury of shadowy shapes tittered and hissed. Dream finally spoke, voice smooth as midnight oil. “Mora. You do not deny invading a crafted recurring dreamscape without consent.” She shrugged. “Territory’s territory. The Dreaming is fluid. I was hungry. The boy had plenty of breath. And frankly, your honor, his ‘innocent’ little fantasy was ripe for some shadow.” First Love’s face was flushed with outrage — or heartbreak, it was hard to tell. “Max deserves peace and sweetness. His heart is tender —” Mora cut in. “—And hearts are tastiest when tender.” Dream’s patience was clearly thinning. “First Love, your craft has a place. But so does shadow and nightmare. The question is one of *balance*. Max’s dream was… excessively saccharine.” First Love gasped. “Are you suggesting—?” Dream almost smiled, a dangerous curve of his lips. “Too much sweetness rots the teeth, as mortals say.” Mora bared her teeth in a grin. “Exactly. I’m just the spice in his stew.” “Or the arsenic,” First Love muttered. Dream’s fingers drummed on the throne’s armrest, echoing like thunder. “Enough. This is not a mortal court, but the domain of stories and shadows. You squabble like children over a sandbox.” Mora snickered. “Well, it’s a juicy sandbox.” The bailiff intoned again, mispronunciation echoing like doom: “CALLING... MAXIMILIAN, THE SLEEPER.” A ghostly projection of the boy shimmered into view — tousled hair, soft freckles, a hint of dream-dazed confusion on his sleeping face. An innocent soul, caught between blushes and nightmares. Dream regarded the image. “Here lies our subject. Neither of you truly own this dream. It is a *reflection* of him, not your canvas to deface or devour.” First Love nodded eagerly. “Exactly! It’s his journey — his becoming.” Mora pouted. “And yet, without a little darkness, becoming *what*? A fool blinded by fantasy? Fear teaches too.” Dream’s voice darkened. “Indeed. Both love and terror shape the soul.” First Love looked as if he’d swallowed a lemon. “You can’t mean to let *her* keep mangling my work? Max will never trust affection again!” Mora stretched, languid and feline. “Or he’ll learn that love is dangerous, thrilling, worth a little risk. Maybe even worth losing breath over.” The bailiff boomed, “ORDER!” though it sounded more like “ODOR!” and several dream-creatures snickered. Dream’s lips twitched — annoyance, or perhaps amusement. “This court grows weary of your quarrel. Both your crafts have merit, yet neither is absolute.” He rose from the throne, shadows swirling in agitation. “Therefore, I decree this: Max’s dream shall remain a *tangle* of sweetness and shadow. On some nights, First Love’s innocence shall reign — wildflowers, blushes, almost-kisses.” First Love brightened, hopeful. Dream continued, “On others, Mora may slip through — to remind him of danger, hunger, the thrill beneath the sweetness.” Mora’s grin sharpened. “Fair’s fair.” First Love looked crestfallen. “But… what of his peace?” Dream’s tone turned wry, almost mischievous. “Peace is not always what mortals need. Sometimes confusion, longing, and a touch of fear are the best teachers.” He glanced at the projection of Max, whose slumbering brow furrowed subtly, no doubt caught between bliss and terror even now. Dream seated himself once more, eyes glittering with ancient mischief. “Besides, it will be… instructive to watch which part of the dream the boy comes to seek — and which he flees.” First Love sighed. “A cruel sort of mercy.” Mora licked her lips. “Or a merciful sort of cruelty.” Dream inclined his head. “The Dreaming is not your playground, nor your pantry. It is the forge of mortal souls. Play your parts, but remember — the story belongs to *him*.” He waved a hand dismissively, shadows gathering like a closing curtain. “Case adjourned.” The bailiff’s parting bellow sounded suspiciously like “DISMISSED!” but came out as “DISMIST!” sending a swirl of fog across the floor as Mora dissolved into mist and First Love into a sigh of spring breeze. The Court emptied, leaving Dream alone with his thoughts and a faint, sardonic smile. He had, perhaps, made the boy’s dreams more complex — and more dangerous. But then, such was the way of dreams: a little sweetness, a touch of terror, and always a mystery in between. He settled back into shadow, awaiting the next absurd squabble, already half-dreading, half-amused at the endless theatre of mortal dreaming.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively creates a dark fantasy courtroom scene with comedic elements as requested. The writer has captured the essence of Neil Gaiman's Sandman universe, particularly in the portrayal of Dream (Morpheus) as a powerful, slightly irritated entity forced to adjudicate petty disputes. The characterization of First Love as a blushing, nervous entity and Mora as a seductive yet terrifying nightmare spirit creates an effective contrast that drives the narrative. The humor works well through several mechanisms: the mispronunciations of the bailiff ("FURST LOOOF!" and "ODOR!" instead of "ORDER!"), the bickering between First Love and Mora, and Dream's sardonic reactions to their squabble. The dark comedy emerges naturally from the situation rather than feeling forced. The prose is generally strong, with vivid imagery that establishes the otherworldly setting without becoming excessive. Descriptions like "Great pillars shimmered with impossible geometries; the air itself rippled with whispers of half-remembered lullabies and primal fears" efficiently create atmosphere without overwhelming the reader. The dialogue effectively reveals character and advances the plot. Mora's casual "A girl's gotta eat too, you know?" and her suggestion that "the line between terror and desire is very thin" establish her as both threatening and darkly humorous. First Love's indignation provides an effective counterpoint. The resolution is appropriately ambiguous and mischievous, with Dream deciding that Max will experience both types of dreams, partly out of curiosity about which the boy will ultimately prefer. This fits the prompt's request for Dream to be "tempted to some mischief in the resolution." There are a few minor weaknesses. Some sentences could be tightened for greater impact, and occasionally the imagery becomes slightly overwrought. The piece also relies somewhat heavily on established Sandman lore and aesthetics rather than creating something entirely original, though this is appropriate given the prompt. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully balances dark fantasy with understated humor while creating engaging characters and an interesting conflict.
